DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Tories on attack over local tax: Curry's claim to undercut Labour council charges by average Pounds 129 disputed
DOC.BYLINE: By JAMES BLITZ and JOHN AUTHERS
DOC.TEXT: The Conservative party yesterday signalled that it will place what it claims are the high levels of council tax levied by Labour-controlled authorities at the forefront of its campaign for May's local council elections. At the party's first campaign news conference for the elections, Mr David Curry, local government minister, unveiled figures suggesting that nine of the 10 highest council taxes levied in the next financial year would be in Labour councils. He also said that, of the 10 lowest taxes, five would be levied by Conservative controlled councils, including Westminster, Wandsworth and Ealing. But Labour said he had chosen an invalid base of comparison, by assessing every council on the tax charged to households in band C - which applies to properties valued between Pounds 52,000 and Pounds 68,000. Figures from the Labour-controlled Association of Metropolitan Authorities showed that 82 per cent of households in Liverpool, which has the most expensive band C tax, lived in properties below the band C threshold, and would therefore pay less than the amount quoted by Mr Curry. In Westminster, with the lowest band C tax, 84 per cent of households are in properties valued above Pounds 68,000, and would therefore pay more. Mr Curry said that the government had been officially notified of the precise levels of council tax to be levied by about 300 of the 419 local authorities in England and Wales. He said that the figures showed that on average councils were levying tax increases of 2.7 per cent in the band C range. Although the survey is not complete, this is nearly 4 percentage points below the amount that the government predicted last autumn, when announcing its grant settlement for 1994-95, and may reflect the determination of councils to contain taxes in an election year. Mr Curry said that on the information the government had received Labour councils would charge Pounds 129 more on average in council tax next year than Conservative councils. He said that larger council tax bills were often levied by councils - such as Lambeth, Tower Hamlets and Islington - which already receive above average grants from central government. Mr Curry said: 'What we can demonstrate is that we can provide better value for money and provide better services.' Mr Jack Straw, shadow local government minister, said that Mr Curry's figures were 'unconvincing'. He said: 'You can't trust the Tories to tell the truth on tax, whether it's on VAT, personal allowances or council tax. They cannot resist twisting the truth.' --------------------------------------------------------------------- COUNTDOWN TO THE LOCAL ELECTIONS: TWO WAYS OF LOOKING AT THE COUNCIL TAX --------------------------------------------------------------------- 'Most expensive' Tory figs Lab figs (Pounds) --------------------------------------------------------------------- Liverpool NOC 770 82% Manchester LAB 691 83% Newcastle LAB 686 75% Coventry LAB 669 72% Salford LAB 658 77% Bristol LAB 652 61% Middlesbrough LAB 645 73% Hartlepool LAB 643 79% Kirklees LAB 635 65% Rossendale LAB 634 69% --------------------------------------------------------------------- 'Least expensive' Tory figs Lab figs --------------------------------------------------------------------- Westminster CON 218 84% Wellingborough CON 261 18% Wandsworth CON 306 58% Isles of Scilly IND 358 92% City of London IND 368 89% Hambleton CON 396 48% Tewkesbury NOC 398 41% Rochester NOC 402 21% Sth Cambridgeshire NOC 408 54% Ealing CON 418 66% --------------------------------------------------------------------- NOC: no overall control Source: DoE/AMA --------------------------------------------------------------------- Tory figures show tax payable for properties in Band C Labour figures show proportion of households paying less than Band C rate in the most expensive authorities; and more than the Band C rate in the least expensive authorities ---------------------------------------------------------------------

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Balfour wins rail link work
DOC.TEXT: Balfour Beatty Civil Engineering yesterday won the Pounds 60m main contract to build the underground stations and tunnels for the Heathrow Express project, Paul Betts writes. The Pounds 300m joint project by BAA, the privatised airports group, and British Rail is to construct an express rail link between Heathrow and the centre of London. The service, scheduled to start operating in December 1997, will mean that the world's busiest international airport can be reached from Paddington Station in 16 minutes. BAA said trains would run every 15 minutes. The project would create 1,800 jobs during construction and a further 200 during operation, said Mr Rod Hoare, Heathrow Express managing director.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Building societies aim to shake off shackles: A look at the controversy over the limits to their activities
DOC.TEXT: Even the largest building societies believe they should get a little extra help from the government to compete effectively in the mortgage and savings markets. At its meeting today the Building Societies Association council will discuss a paper on the current review of the 1986 legislation on building societies. Announcing the review in January, Mr Anthony Nelson, the Treasury economic secretary, highlighted for discussion areas such as the limit of 40 per cent of funds which societies can raise on the wholesale markets; merger and takeover procedures; and the process for societies to change their status. The BSA, to which the Treasury has sub-contracted much of the consultation process, believes the chance of a full review - with the ending of legislative constraints on societies - should not be missed. Mr Adrian Coles, association director-general, says some detailed changes it would like could be done reasonably quickly as part of the de-regulation initiative. Mr Donald Kirkham, chief executive of Woolwich building society, the UK's third largest, says: 'In fundamental terms, the only thing really pressing down on building societies is the wholesale funding limit.' Societies want greater access to wholesale funds, where borrowing is cheaper at present, so they can offer more attractive deals to potential borrowers. For much of last year they lost market share to the banks. But for the medium term, the association would still like an end to legislative limits on the powers of societies, except those needed to define their mutual status. One suggestion for defining mutuality, set out in an association paper about 18 months ago, is that a society should raise a set proportion of its funds from its members and have a set proportion of its commercial assets as loans to members. Removing the existing constraints on what societies can do would inevitably mean changes to the way they are regulated. The paper was tactful enough to say it would prefer the Building Societies Commission to remain the regulator, but acknowledged the argument for moving supervision to the Bank of England as differences between banks and societies diminish. That prospect was raised by the Bank itself when Mr Brian Quinn, an executive director, gave evidence to the influential Commons Treasury committee of MPs last November. Mr John Watts, the Tory chairman of the committee, says it will pursue this issue when it takes evidence from the commission and the association during its current inquiry into financial regulation. There are also broader concerns at Westminster. Mr Alistair Darling, Labour's City spokesman, says: 'The legislation should allow societies to expand their activities. 'But I would be very reluctant to give them carte blanche to do whatever they like.' As Mr Coles puts it, the issue is one of efficiency: no matter how amenable the Building Societies Commission has been, the need for changes in societies' powers to be considered by parliament inevitably means delay. He says: 'Building societies don't want the ability to lend in Bosnia and Brazil. 'The change would allow us to do things in the markets where we operate in the most efficient way possible.' But others question whether societies are trying to seize an unfair advantage, given the protected environment in which they exist and the lack of shareholders to hold boards accountable. Mr Peter Birch, chief executive of Abbey National, the former society which converted to plc status in 1989, dismisses the argument that societies are fully accountable to their members. He says that most savers and borrowers do not see themselves as having a controlling role in the society. 'When people go into a building society, they do so because the goods are attractive, rather than to become members,' he says. His comments seem borne out by members' involvement. For example, at Halifax building society, the UK's largest, only about 10 per cent of its 5.5m voting members took part in decisions at last year's annual general meeting. Even at Nationwide, the second largest, where the running of the society became such an issue that members insisted on a couple of their own candidates becoming directors, only about 103,000 of the 3.5m voting members were involved in voting for the board at last year's AGM. Mr David Gilchrist, Halifax corporate development manager, describes the society as 'happy to look at ways of improving accountability'. But far from enhancing accountability, the most likely immediate changes from the de-regulation initiative may reduce the prospects for internal democracy, since they are directed at streamlining the occasions and ways for societies to consult and notify their millions of members. Society chief executives are reluctant to concede the point publicly, but some privately admit that greater freedoms should be accompanied by more accountability.
DOC.IN: P6162 Mortgage Bankers and Correspondents. P9651 Regulation of Miscellaneous Commercial Sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Court to rule on review of councils
DOC.TEXT: The High Court will decide tomorrow on applications by three local authorities for judicial review of the Local Government Commission's proposals for council re-organisation in north-east England. A government decision on the area has already been delayed. The commission said it had failed to consider about 500 letters from local interests that were sent before the closing date for consultation. As a result an unprecedented supplementary report on the area will be published. It seems unlikely, however, that the supplementary report will make significant changes to the recommendations. Mr John Gummer, the environment secretary, must wait until the commission's reports are complete before announcing any decisions on the area. If the appeal for judicial review is successful, the process could be further delayed. Humberside and North Yorkshire county councils, and Ryedale, a district within North Yorkshire, are all dissatisfied with recommendations which would see the creation of five all-purpose unitary councils north of the Humber in place of the current two-tier system. They say the commission failed to consider properly the possibility of maintaining the two-tier status quo, and to carry out proper consultations. The Labour-controlled Association of County Councils said it was 'concerned' by the commission's 'worrying' mistake. It will instruct its members in areas not yet reviewed to check that all submissions have been considered by the commission. The cross-party Association of District Councils, whose members include Ryedale, discourages districts from resorting to judicial review, as the process is costly and delays re-organisation. Five counties - Avon, Cleveland, Derbyshire, Lancashire and Somerset - have already been allowed to challenge commission decisions in the High Court. The judicial reviews for Avon, Somerset and Cleveland will take place on May 23. In the following two weeks the commission, which is working to a timetable shortened by the government last September, must announce proposals for re-organising Bedfordshire, Berkshire, Leicestershire, Oxfordshire, Cambridgeshire, Suffolk, Staffordshire, Cheshire, Cumbria, Hampshire and Devon. Proposals for Kent and Devon may also be announced at the same time, if severe local disagreements in both areas can be overcome.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Stress on jobless takes heavy toll
DOC.TEXT: Unemployed people are 75 per cent more likely to experience a marriage break-up than those in work, says the most comprehensive survey of employment and joblessness in Britain. The four-year study, based on 6,000 individuals in six towns, found that in spite of experiencing multiple deprivations the unemployed are not becoming a culturally distinct 'underclass'. It also found that they are flexible in the work they are prepared to undertake and have only modest pay expectations. Almost all unemployed individuals are considerably worse off on benefits than in work - but married women are more likely to give up work when husbands become unemployed because of benefits rules. The survey covered Aberdeen, Coventry, Kirkcaldy, Northampton, Rochdale and Swindon. It is part of the Social Change and Economic Life Initiative funded by the Economic and Social Research Council. It is published today in the book Social Change and the Experience of Unemployment (Oxford University Press). Average labour costs in manufacturing are lower in the UK than southern Italy, one of the poorest regions of the European Union, says a report published by the Low Pay Unit yesterday. But the research group says the UK's success in creating jobs has been much less than in countries with higher levels of employment and social protection.
DOC.IN: P9441 Administration of Social and Manpower Programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Mercury to spend Pounds 200m on network
DOC.TEXT: Mercury, the main rival to British Telecommunications in the UK, will today announce a Pounds 200m upgrading programme aimed at increasing its capacity to compete in the provision of advanced telecoms services. The investment in 'intelligent networks' technology will give Mercury one of the most advanced networks in Europe, able to offer new features such as corporate phone 'meetings'. The main contractor is DSC, a fast-growing US supplier specialising in intelligent networks technology, which is installing similar systems for several US regional Bell companies. Other contractors include Northern Telecom, the Canadian supplier, and GPT, the UK-based joint venture between General Electric Company and Siemens, the German group. Investment for the first year is expected to approach Pounds 20m, with new services coming on stream as early as next year. Cable Wireless, Mercury's parent company, intends to spread the technology to other operators under its control, including Hong Kong Telecom. DSC already has a contract with Optus, the main rival to the former state monopoly in Australia, which is part-owned by CW. 'Intelligent networks' are sophisticated signalling and computer systems giving operators the power to route calls and programme local exchanges without having to install software and hardware at each exchange. They also offer operators large efficiency and reliability gains. The investment underlines CW's long-term commitment to Mercury, despite its avowed intention to concentrate future investment in the Asia-Pacific region. It also points the way to future competition between operators not just on price, as now, but also on the range of sophistication of services, as in the US.
DOC.IN: P4813 Telephone Communications, Ex Radio.
DOC.TP: RES Capital expenditures. RES Facilities. TECH Services Services use.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Labour attacks Major over inflation 'rift'
DOC.TEXT: Labour yesterday seized on remarks about inflation by the prime minister and the deputy governor of the Bank of England to claim that the two were 'completely at odds'. Mr John Major said yesterday that inflation was 'under lock and key'. Mr Rupert Pennant-Rea said it was 'a delusion' to think that Britain had defeated inflation. Mr Gordon Brown, the shadow chancellor, said: 'The prime minister should clarify his precise inflation target and whether he intends to meet it.' Mr Pennant-Rea told the Institute of Credit Management national conference: 'It is tempting to feel that Britain has won the war against inflation, so we can now afford to relax. That is a delusion, and a dangerous one too.' Underlying inflation, which excludes mortgage payments, was 2.8 per cent in January, still in the top half of the government's 1 per cent to 4 per cent target range. The Bank said in its inflation report, published in February, that the underlying rate would remain in the top half of the range throughout 1995, and there was an 'asymmetric risk' it would move higher. Mr Pennant-Rea said: 'We have to keep inflation down in order to sustain growth. Monetary restraint is not a hair-shirt but it has to be a habit. After all the unforced errors of the past it will take many years to prove we have acquired it.' Mr Major, speaking to businessmen in Portsmouth, was rather more upbeat about inflation than Mr Pennant-Rea, but his comments about the UK's economic prospects were in tune with those of the deputy governor. The prime minister said: 'What I believe we are beginning to get is a satisfactory platform for sustained recovery with low inflation.' Mr Pennant-Rea said: 'The economy will soon enter its third year of recovery, and the pace of that recovery is enough to have started reducing unemployment. Meanwhile, inflation is low and the government's target is for it to go lower still.' Mr Pennant-Rea's speech marked a departure in tone from the customary solemn phraseology of top Bank officials. In a candid passage about past mistakes in monetary policy, he said: 'At the Bank of England we are merely part of the supply lines. As such, we have the ability to mess things up - and our record shows we have often used it.'
DOC.IN: P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Open minister suffers brush with the truth: A look at the aftermath of a verbal slip-up
DOC.BYLINE: By PHILIP STEPHENS and JOHN WILLMAN
DOC.TEXT: In Mr William Waldegrave's judgment the turning point came early yesterday morning. Emerging, still blinking with sleep, from the front door of his London home he was met by a barrage of questions from waiting journalists. 'Are you going to resign, Mr Waldegrave?' shouted one. 'Why?' responded the minister for public services and science. 'For telling the truth,' the journalist yelled back. Mr Waldegrave decided he could relax. The row about his public comments on when governments might or might not consciously mislead parliament was revealing itself as a media storm in a Westminster teacup. Speaking a few hours later to the Social Market Foundation Mr Waldegrave was careful not to blame the media. Instead he quoted Enoch Powell's dictum that a politician who complains about the media is like a sailor who complains about the sea: 'We amateur sailors often complain about the sea, but it does us little good.' An honest politician in a government which has not won many prizes for giving straight answers, Mr Waldegrave spent the rest of the day in television and radio studios explaining what he had originally said to a Commons committee. No, he had not suggested that it was proper for ministers to mislead parliament. Instead, he had pointed to two occasions in the distant past on which ministers had been economical with the truth about impending devaluations of the pound. The row rumbled on. Lord Callaghan protested that he had evaded parliamentary questions but had never told a lie. Opposition politicians saw another opportunity to pin the 'sleaze' label on an ever-embattled government. Mr Waldegrave's enemies on the right wing of the Tory party saw another opportunity to cast him as an inevitable victim of the next cabinet reshuffle. After all, he might well face considerable criticism in the report of the Scott inquiry into arms-related exports to Iraq. Mr Major could offer him as a convenient scapegoat. But thoughtful colleagues believe sacking Mr Waldegrave in the summer would be a mistake. He may not be the most guileful of politicians but he is an intelligent one. His donnish approach to politics is in refreshing contrast to the instinctively combative approaches of Mr Michael Howard or Mr Kenneth Clarke. And if he has never courted a constituency among backbench Tory MPs, he does have the powerful support of Mr Douglas Hurd. During regular appearances before select committees he conducts a genuine dialogue with backbenchers, acknowledging the force of criticisms and enjoying reasoned argument with those of contrary views. His handling of the government's science policy has won him plaudits. His oversight of the Citizen's Charter has made the best of a bad job. This week he made a mistake. His desire to answer MPs' questions led him to acknowledge a practice that every politician knows to be true but which few ever admit. In more tranquil times no one would have noticed. But the media pounces now on every slip - even, it seems, when the minister responsible for open government tells the truth.
DOC.IN: P9199 General Government, NEC.
DOC.TP: GOVT Government News. CMMT Comment Analysis.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Waldegrave says he will not resign
DOC.TEXT: Mr William Waldegrave yesterday said he had no intention of resigning as the minister for public services and science over his comments that ministers had to lie in exceptional circumstances. But as the prime minister gave his public backing to his cabinet colleague, Downing Street was forced on to the defensive by a request from Lord Callaghan for Mr Waldegrave to 'clear my name'. This was after Mr Waldegrave said the former Labour prime minister had told untruths during the devaluation crisis of 1967. Clearly angered by Mr Waldegrave's comments, Lord Callaghan emphasised that he had chosen his words very carefully, but that he had never lied to the Commons. Comments later released on behalf of Mr Waldegrave sought to make it clear that the minister had not criticised Lord Callaghan's actions. The comments stressed that the former prime minister was working 'in extremely difficult circumstances'. Mr Waldegrave 'specifically recognised Mr Callaghan's difficulties and believed he behaved with propriety. If Lord Callaghan now feels that Mr Waldegrave has impugned his integrity it is very clear that is not the case.' Downing Street described the devaluations under Labour governments in 1949 and 1967 as 'exceptional circumstances in unusual times'. It was clear, however, that Mr John Major continued to believe ministers 'must be truthful and not mislead the Commons'. Mr Waldegrave had pointed to two Labour chancellors, Lord Callaghan and Sir Stafford Cripps, who had been forced to mislead the Commons in order to try to prevent the devaluation of the pound. Mr Major said: 'Mr Waldegrave answered an intelligent question frankly about what had happened under another government a quarter of a century ago.' The prime minister was asked on the BBC whether lying could be justified in parliament. He replied: 'Nobody can and nobody does.' Mr Waldegrave, asked by Jimmy Young on BBC Radio 2 whether he thought he was going to keep his job, replied: 'That is entirely up to the prime minister. If ministers are going to be fired for telling the truth, we are going to get into a very difficult pickle.' Mr Waldegrave later told his colleagues that he had no intention of resigning. Asked earlier if he had blundered by being too honest, he said: 'If the new line of attack is to say we really don't want ministers to tell the truth on these matters, we want ministers who give weasel words, I suppose I plead guilty.'
DOC.IN: P9199 General Government, NEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Pay group raps failure to create jobs
DOC.TEXT: Average labour costs in manufacturing are lower in the UK than southern Italy, one of the poorest regions of the European Union, a report published by the Low Pay Unit yesterday shows. But it says the UK's success in creating jobs has been much less than countries with a higher level of employment and social protection. The research group said: 'Italy created proportionately six times as many jobs as the UK between 1970 and 1992. Germany created almost four times as many jobs and France created twice as many.' De-regulation, it said, had not allowed the UK to create employment and it had not delivered prosperity. 'It has helped to create a situation in which 40 per cent or more of the UK workforce are employed on a part-time, temporary or casual basis, or are classed as freelance or self-employed.' The unit said the UK was uncompetitive because productivity was low, pushing unit labour costs to a level very much higher than the EU average. In part the UK's low productivity was a result of long working hours and poor conditions of employment. Staff turnover and absenteeism were high by European standards and training was poor. 'These factors were directly related to the low wages themselves,' it said. De-regulation: Britain Pays the Price. Low Pay Unit 27-29 Amwell Street, London EC1R 1UN. Free
DOC.IN: P9441 Administration of Social and Manpower Programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Auditors split on cap to liability
DOC.TEXT: Medium-size accountancy firms yesterday started to fight back against the campaign by their larger competitors to limit the exposure of auditors to big litigation claims. Mr Peter Douglas, national managing partner of Kidsons Impey, the UK's 12th-largest firm, said he was considering organising a group of mid-size firms to object to proposals which would allow auditors to cap their liability at a multiple of audit fees. 'I just find it difficult that auditors should be given some protection against being negligent,' he said. His comments follow the decision by the ruling council of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales last week to support a paper in favour of reform to be sent to the Department of Trade and Industry. The institute is echoing a campaign being run by the UK's largest eight accounting firms calling for removal of section 310 of the 1985 Companies Act, which forbids auditors to negotiate any limit on their liability. A number of partners from smaller firms have objected to the campaign as being self-interested and serving the interests of the larger firms. Mr Douglas, who joins the institute's council in June, said he had arranged a meeting on the subject with Mr Neil Hamilton, minister for corporate affairs at the DTI. 'The larger firms are not in the same market as the rest of us, and that is because they have tried very hard to ensure we are not,' he said. Mr Graham Ward, a partner with Price Waterhouse, has argued that part of the case for reform is that executors of wills of deceased accountancy firm partners were restricting payments to their widows and children because they could not quantify the risk of future liabilities the estates might incur as a result of litigation settlements.
DOC.IN: P8721 Accounting, Auditing, and Bookkeeping Services.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Political Notebook: Inelegant and inevitable U-turn made on Bosnia
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks ago the message was crystal clear. Britain had provided more than its fair share of ground troops for Bosnia. If the United Nations needed additional forces then it would fall to others - most notably the US - to do their bit. Just seven days ago the consensus within the cabinet remained opposed to reinforcing the 2,000-strong British contingent in the former Yugoslav province. Mr Douglas Hurd said so in untypically blunt terms in a newspaper article. Now the government has reversed itself. It has decided it must lead the international effort to give General Sir Michael Rose the additional 10,500 soldiers he wants to police the growing number of ceasefires in Bosnia. The cabinet is expected to approve later today the despatch of another 1,000 or so British soldiers. A few other countries will commit extra troops. But by its own yardstick the British government will be doing a great deal more than its fair share. It has been an inelegant U-turn. It is fraught with political risks. If there is anything approaching a consensus on the Tory backbenches it is driven by the instinct that Britain should avoid deeper military entanglement. Nor has the shift been without critics in the senior ranks of the government. No one in the cabinet - from the prime minister downwards - has been an enthusiast for an enhanced military role. But over recent weeks four distinct camps have emerged. One, led by the prime minister, has been convinced by the case for more muscular action on the ground to accompany the latest drive for a political settlement. A second, including Mr Hurd, has gradually aligned itself with that view. Mr Malcolm Rifkind has headed a third group of more cautious ministers arguing against extra troops until a broad political deal has been struck. Finally, Mr Kenneth Clarke and, to a lesser extent, Mr Michael Heseltine have put the case against further military involvement in almost any circumstances. The balance of power has been shifting constantly. But since Friday - when Mr Major took a decision in principle to commit extra troops - the initiative has passed decisively to the interventionist camp. The most important element in the change of heart was the pledge offered to Mr Major by President Bill Clinton to maintain US pressure on the Bosnian Moslems to reach a political settlement. With the Russians applying similar pressure on the Serbs and the Germans on the Croats, that held out a reasonable prospect of an eventual end to the civil war. It offered also a not-to-be-missed opportunity to draw a line under the acrimonious disputes with Washington that have poisoned British-American relations for more than a year. The change in the international environment coincided with the success of General Rose in gradually extending the ceasefire in Sarajevo to other areas. That in turn opened up the possibility of a 'bottom-up' peace process - with a series of regional truces providing additional momentum towards an overall settlement. Britain could hardly jeopardise the process for the sake of a few hundred troops. But the clinching factor in the new equation was the demand by General Rose for additional British troops. Though he couched his public demands in terms of the UN, he left no doubt that his first priority was for additional experienced British soldiers. Ministers, who had consistently stated that the government's military strategy would be guided by the commanders, could hardly ignore warnings that British forces were being 'stretched to breaking point'. For most in the cabinet - with the exception of Mr Clarke - the case for reinforcement has become irresistible. Mr Major will claim that Britain is taking an important lead. But it was the force of circumstance which made this latest U-turn as inevitable as it was inelegant.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs. P9199 General Government, NEC.
DOC.TP: GOVT Government News. CMMT Comment Analysis.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Company-car drivers confess to sins
DOC.TEXT: Company-car drivers are nearly twice as likely to break motorway speed limits than private motorists. They also break speed limits on other main roads more readily and admit to parking illegally more often. This unflattering portrait of company-car drivers is set out in the latest annual survey of the business-car community by polling organisation MORI and Pragma Consulting. The survey was commissioned by Lex Vehicle Leasing, owned by Lex Service and finance house Lombard North Central. MORI's soundings among fleet managers about the differences between men and women found that 'in general women are thought (by fleet managers) to be better and safer drivers and that they look after their vehicles better'. Younger fleet managers were more likely to feel that women made better drivers. More pertinent in terms of the costs incurred by companies on repairs and insurance premiums, when asked 'Who in your organisation has most accidents?', 43 per cent of the managers said men and 54 per cent saw little difference. Only 4 per cent said women. The survey concludes that the percentage of company cars, at 11.3 per cent of the total, is higher than for several years and that the population has increased by 50,000 in the past 12 months. The average age of the cars has fallen from 2.8 years to 2.5 years in the past 12 months, indicating that companies are increasing the replacement rate. Mr John Walden, Lex Vehicle Leasing's managing director, sees this as a sign that business confidence is improving. He said: 'Companies make investment decisions, like replacing company vehicles, when they are confident that the business climate is improving. The survey results . . . clearly indicate a turnaround in business outlook'. Only 1 per cent of company-car drivers surveyed said their companies were phasing out company cars. More than 4,000 stolen cars were offered for sale to dealers in the last quarter of last year, reflecting a continuing surge in car-related crime and fraud, according to HPI, the vehicle information tracking agency. HPI also found last-quarter increases in vehicles written off by insurance companies being repaired and re-offered for sale, and more cars being offered for sale while still subject to hire-purchase agreements. The agency makes about 3.5m vehicle-background checks a year for auction houses and the motor trade. Mr Brian Bailey, HPI's chairman, said part of the rise was likely to be seasonal and related to financial pressures in the approach to Christmas. But there was also a 'worrying underlying trend' driving the statistics upwards. 1994 Lex Report on Motoring - The Company View. DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Treasury stalls Tube gates deal
DOC.TEXT: London Underground is attempting to win Treasury approval for a Pounds 4m deal to lease automatic access gates for 12 of its busiest stations but has yet to reach an agreement on the financing terms. This is the second time within a month that a London Underground proposal to bring in private finance to pay for investments has met Treasury objections. A Pounds 500m deal to lease 100 trains for the Northern Line from ABB Transportation has also run into difficulties with Treasury rules. The latest deal involves a proposal from Westinghouse Cubic, a maker of revenue collection and control systems, to supply automatic gates for busy stations on the Underground including Harrow-on-the-Hill, Uxbridge, Whitechapel, Hammersmith, Balham and Morden. The others are East Ham, Edgware, Tooting Broadway, Gants Hill, Leyton and Plaistow. Treasury talks are understood to have run into problems over the transfer of risk to Westinghouse Cubic. The Underground is believed to have suggested that payments be linked to the number of passengers using the stations, but the Treasury wanted it tied to the success of the gates in reducing fraud. London Underground said that if agreement on the leasing deal could not be reached, it would fund the project from its own resources if forced to. It was, however, hopeful of reaching Treasury agreement. London Underground is keen to extend the use of gates to combat fraud, which costs it Pounds 30m a year. The government has attempted for several years to persuade the private sector to finance public transport infrastructure schemes, but with only limited success. A private finance panel was set up last autumn to identify promising projects and remove blockages to implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Beef ban threat begins to hit trade
DOC.TEXT: German threats to impose a ban on British beef imports because of fears over 'mad cow' disease (bovine spongiform encephalopathy) had already had 'disastrous' effects on the meat trade for at least one company, Mrs Gillian Shephard, agriculture minister, said yesterday. 'It is having a disastrous effect on the company's trade with Germany and affecting inquiries from elsewhere. I'm simply not having it,' she said. Mrs Shephard is preparing a dossier for her German counterparts on the effect of renewed publicity over BSE on meat exports. Germany has called for a special session of European Union health ministers this month to discuss a ban on British beef imports. Mrs Shephard said she hoped the Germans would withdraw their request because it is supported by no other EU member country. Mr Mike Roper, export manager of Buchan Meats in Turriff, Aberdeenshire, said business with Germany had fallen 15 per cent in the past year because of renewed fears over BSE as well as the recession. He said: 'We provide a guarantee that our beef is BSE-free, but this is a popular issue in Germany and there is a lot of concern about it.' Germany imported about 900,000 tonnes of beef last year, but only 1,000 tonnes was from Britain - less than 1 per cent of total British beef exports to the EU. British beef exports to the EU - 126,000 tonnes last year - have only begun to take off in recent years. The German health ministry said yesterday it would take no unilateral action to ban British beef if the planned meeting of EU health ministers could prove that no risks were involved in importing meat which may be contaminated with BSE.
DOC.CN: GBZ United Kingdom, EC. DEZ Germany, EC.
DOC.IN: P5147 Meats and Meat Products. P201 Meat Products.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Peace slips further from grasp: A look at the damage to the talks process
DOC.BYLINE: By DAVID OWEN and MICHAEL CASSELL
DOC.TEXT: British and Irish ministers will meet in London today in the aftermath of last night's failed IRA mortar spectacular. They will be even more determined to demonstrate that there will be no let up in the search for peace in Northern Ireland. Privately, however, they concede they face a long hard haul. The window of opportunity, opened with December's Downing Street declaration, appears to be creaking shut. The early hopes of imminent peace, today even more difficult to sustain, have become bogged down in political diversions which threaten to derail the two governments' initiative. For London and Dublin, the challenge more than ever is to keep the show on the road, to build on the genuine consensus which now exists between the two governments and to insist that their broader, bolder objectives will not be sidetracked by mortars or sub-plots. It is not going to be easy. The wave of mass killings last autumn, which gave impetus to intensified Anglo-Irish efforts to forge a durable settlement, has subsided, lowering the sense of urgency which underpinned a renewed readiness among the province's political parties to compromise. On the political front, the European elections beckon. As a result, the province's main political parties are already adopting a markedly more aggressive tone in discussing the prospects for a settlement. The Ulster Unionists are particularly mindful of the need to protect their flank against the Rev Ian Paisley's hardline Democratic Unionists. London has all but abandoned hope of reaching the stage where round-table talks between Ulster's main non-violent parties and the two governments can be resurrected until the elections are out of the way. In Dublin there is also, in the words of one Northern Ireland Office official, 'an acute awareness of the Ulster calendar'. In addition, the lengthening silence from Sinn Fein - punctuated by potentially murderous assaults - is increasingly being seen in both capitals as the republican movement's way of saying no to the declaration. A surprise acceptance or semi-acceptance, even now, has not been completely ruled out. But few expect anything from Sinn Fein that would enable any significant headway to be made this side of Euro-polling day on June 9. Not surprisingly, both governments are playing down expectations for today's session. All the more so since attention is expected to focus on strand two of the three-stranded process: relations between Dublin and the north. This, by common consent, is the most difficult circle the talks process will have to square. As Lord Fitt, the former leader of the Roman Catholic Social Democratic and Labour party, told his fellow peers last week: 'It is strand two that will cause all the difficulties. It has done so in the past and will undoubtedly do the same again in the future.' Today's meeting will take stock of the position, which was in effect done at last weekend's meeting in Dublin between Sir Patrick Mayhew, Northern Ireland Secretary, and Mr Dick Spring, Irish Foreign minister. It will also discuss progress made by the liaison committee, set up after last month's so-called Twickenham summit between Mr John Major, the prime minister, and Mr Albert Reynolds, his Irish counterpart, in reaching a common position on the way ahead. But it is thought too early for significant progress to have been made, making it difficult to publicly demonstrate that the initiative is gathering momentum. Today's meeting will not attract the fanfare that surrounded the Downing Street declaration or the publicity generated by last night's airport raid. But, although peace is apparently as elusive as ever, the intervening two months has done nothing to undermine the quiet determination in London and Dublin to try to finish what they started in September.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs. P9199 General Government, NEC. P8651 Political Organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Heathrow attack a reminder of IRA capabilities
DOC.BYLINE: By MICHAEL CASSELL and JIMMY BURNS
DOC.TEXT: The Heathrow attack served as a potentially devastating reminder of the IRA's continuing capability to strike on the British mainland and to extract maximum publicity for its cause, Michael Cassell and Jimmy Burns write. The mortar assault, although it ended in failure, inevitably gave rise to speculation that an attack on such a high-profile, security-sensitive target provides the IRA's answer to the Downing Street declaration. The organisation prides itself on its independent cell structure which gives considerable autonomy to on-the-ground 'active service units'. But security sources believe it unlikely that such an attack would be planned and mounted without the knowledge of the higher echelons of the IRA command. MI5 and Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist experts have been privately warning for months of the possibility of another 'big one' on the mainland to raise the political stakes. According to security experts, last night's attack would have been planned over several weeks, using an active unit of about three people and an intelligence and support team of at least twice that number. The mortars and explosive material are likely to have been assembled in at least one mainland safe-house or depot although the decision to activate the operation would have come within 24 hours of the attack. In spite of an impression that the IRA wound down activities in the period after the joint declaration, the reality is that its campaign has continued throughout. Until last night, however, it had been confined to Ulster.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs. P9229 Public Order and Safety, NEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / MPs may question Thatcher over Pergau
DOC.BYLINE: By JAMES BLITZ, PAUL TAYLOR and ALEXANDER NICOLL
DOC.TEXT: MPs investigating Britain's offer of Pounds 234m of aid for Malaysia's Pergau dam have not ruled out the prospect of summoning Baroness Thatcher before them in the next few weeks to answer questions on the affair. Members of the Commons foreign affairs committee, which is investigating the aid deal, discussed the possibility of summoning the former prime minister at a private meeting yesterday. The committee confirmed that Lord Howe, foreign secretary when an offer of aid to Malaysia was first discussed, had agreed to give evidence to the committee in the next two weeks. It agreed that a final decision on whether to ask Lady Thatcher to give testimony would be taken after his appearance. One committee member said yesterday: 'We discussed Lady Thatcher, but we decided it would be premature to make a decision at this stage. We want to see how we progress.' The committee has interviewed the main participants in the decision to go ahead with the aid deal, including Mr Douglas Hurd, the foreign secretary, and Lord Younger, who as defence secretary signed a Pounds 1bn arms deal which was 'briely entangled' with the aid package in March 1988. The committee's report should be finished in May or June. Some committee members believe that more evidence is needed to shed light on decision-making on the aid offer, which was described by a senior Foreign Office official as an 'abuse' of the aid system. The committee also agreed yesterday to call officials from Balfour Beatty and Cementation, the construction companies that were contracted to help build the dam. It will also take evidence from pressure groups including Friends of the Earth and the World Development Movement. A spokeswoman for Lady Thatcher said yesterday that she was 'not saying anything on this subject whatsoever' and she did not comment on invitations until they had been received. Meanwhile, BICC, the British cables and construction group which owns Balfour Beatty, said it had received assurances that a Pounds 70m civil engineering contract for work on the new Pounds 3bn Kuala Lumpur airport would not be affected by Malaysia's ban on UK companies participating in new government contracts. Balfour Beatty said it had a letter of intent covering earthworks at the airport site before the ban was imposed. Sir Robin Biggam, BICC's chairman, said Mr Peter Mason, Balfour Beatty's chief executive, had visited Malaysia last week and was told by the government it wanted Balfour to go ahead with the project. On prospects for further contracts Sir Robin said: 'The future is uncertain but we are hoping for the best.' Alexander Nicoll writes: British exports to Asia rose 29 per cent last year to about Pounds 13bn from Pounds 10bn in 1992, and the region is receiving higher priority in the commercial efforts of the Foreign Office, Mr Douglas Hurd, the foreign secretary, said yesterday. DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Mayhew defends N Ireland committee
DOC.TEXT: Sir Patrick Mayhew last night insisted that the establishment of a Northern Ireland select committee would have 'no adverse effect whatsoever' on the Ulster talks process. The Northern Ireland secretary made the assertion as MPs voted to set up such a committee by a majority of 103 (324-221). A Labour amendment to give the body more powers than those proposed by the government was defeated by 58 votes (298-240). The move will be widely seen as a reinforcement of the government's commitment to the province's unionist majority. Another cross-party committee of MPs will now deliberate on the detailed composition of the new body, which may start work soon after Easter. According to Mr Tony Newton, leader of the Commons, ministers have recommended that 13 MPs should sit on it and that the government should be expected 'to be able to command a majority'. The Tory proposals are thought to call for six of the 13 members to be Conservatives, with the government's effective majority kept intact by the presence of Sir James Kilfedder, the usually loyal Ulster Popular Unionist MP for North Down. Sir Patrick was goaded into his one-sentence intervention in last night's debate by a Social Democratic and Labour party claim that government consent for the committee was a 'political act'. Mr Eddie McGrady, SDLP MP for South Down, urged MPs to reject the government's proposal and support political talks between Northern Ireland's main political parties and the peace process 'against which this proposal will impact'. Mr Kevin McNamara, shadow Northern Ireland secretary, accused the government of allowing short-term party interest to take priority over the peace process. The 'primary reason' that the government had conceded a select committee was the need to maintain the 'understanding' reached with the Ulster Unionist party in return for the support of its nine MPs in crucial Maastricht votes. Mr McNamara also complained bitterly about the government's proposals for Labour to have only two seats on the committee and the SDLP only one. Ministers were proposing to 'gerrymander the composition of the committee,' he said. Opposition concerns were partly echoed by Mr Peter Temple-Morris, the Tory MP for Leominster, who warned that the move would be perceived as 'integrationist'. Mr William McCrea, the hardline Democratic Unionist MP for Mid Ulster, said he was 'delighted' that MPs would now have the right to scrutinise Northern Ireland ministers. 'Direct rule is remote. Ministers have to be brought to book,' he said.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Youth wins Pounds 24,000 in sex bias case
DOC.TEXT: Ms Karen Bishop, 17, was awarded more than Pounds 24,000 damages yesterday after winning a sex discrimination case against Cooper Thames Ditton, a BMW car franchise holder based in Surrey. An industrial tribunal in Croydon, south London, decided she had been unfairly denied a mechanic's apprenticeship in favour of two 16-year-old boys because she was female. She was 15 at the time. Ms Bishop said after the hearing: 'I passed my test two weeks ago and drive a Mini. I might use some of the money on a new car, but it won't be a BMW.'

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / BCCI creditors get details of deal
DOC.TEXT: The creditors' committee to the collapsed Bank of Credit and Commerce International is expected to meet the liquidators at the end of next week to give its verdict on a proposed new agreement with the government of Abu Dhabi, the bank's majority shareholder. Representatives met the liquidators from accountants Touche Ross to learn for the first time details of the agreement which was reached in the past few days. The settlement would include a payment of about Dollars 1.8bn (Pounds 1.2bn) from Abu Dhabi and a restructuring of its claims against BCCI in exchange for agreement by the liquidators not to be sued. The agreement had to be renegotiated following a surprise rejection of the original by the Luxembourg appeals court in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Rethink on crime payouts rejected
DOC.TEXT: The government is determined to press ahead with changes to the criminal injuries compensation scheme, in spite of claims that the reforms will unjustly reduce payments to victims, Kevin Brown writes. A senior official said there was no question of a rethink on the proposed changes, which would replace individual assessments with a fixed tariff. Labour said yesterday that the tariff would reduce payments to sexually abused children, families of murder victims and injured police. The reforms have been criticised in the Lords, where peers said they could be unconstitutional and open to judicial review. Mr Michael Howard, the home secretary, is understood to have taken legal advice which supports the government view that the changes can be implemented in April as planned. Downing Street insisted that the scheme would remain the most generous in Europe. Officials said that some payments would rise. Compensation for aggravated rape will rise from an average of Pounds 9,500 to Pounds 10,000, and payments for facial scarring will rise from an average of Pounds 6,000 to Pounds 7,500. However, there was unrest among Conservative backbenchers about the government's admission that the reforms will cut the cost of the scheme from some Pounds 500m to about Pounds 250m a year. It was also disclosed in the Lords last night that Sir Patrick Mayhew, Northern Ireland secretary, is considering extending the changes - which apply to England, Wales and Scotland - to Ulster.
DOC.IN: P92 Justice, Public Order, and Safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Labour refuses to back anti-terrorism order
DOC.TEXT: Attempts by Labour leaders to secure a new cross-party consensus on anti-terrorism legislation ended in acrimony and recrimination in the Commons last night. Mr Michael Howard, the home secretary, seized on the mortar bomb attack on Heathrow airport in a vain appeal to Labour MPs not to vote against an order renewing the Prevention of Terrorism Act for a further 12 months. To government cheers, he said that if the attack was meant to send 'some signal to the House' MPs of all parties should respond by joining together in voting for the order. Labour MPs ignored the home secretary's appeal, angered by his rejection of their pleas for an inquiry by a senior judge into the provisions permitting terrorist suspects to be detained for questioning for up to seven days, and for those from Northern Ireland to be excluded from mainland Britain. The order was approved with a government majority of 86 (328-242). Mr Howard infuriated Labour MPs by repeatedly insisting that their main objective was to escape the political consequences of continuing to vote against the renewal of the Prevention of Terrorism Act. In a series of clashes Mr Tony Blair, shadow home secretary, accused Mr Howard of 'ranting' in the hope of securing party advantage by accentuating the divide between the two main parties. Mr Blair suggested that the government's partisan approach had been signalled in advance of the debate by the leaking of information about last week's confidential talks on the operation of the act between Mr John Smith, the Labour leader, and Mr John Major, the prime minister. Like the prime minister, Mr Howard denied that the leak originated from the Home Office, either through civil servants or political advisers, or other government sources. Mr Smith issued a statement underlining his dissatisfaction with the outcome of the inquiry ordered by the prime minister, which had been carried out 'in little more than 24 hours'. He added: 'I remain deeply disturbed both at the leak and at Mr Major's failure to discover its source.' Mr David Trimble, chief spokesman in the debate for the Ulster Unionists, reaffirmed support for the renewal of the act but agreed with some points made by Labour. He suggested that a judicial officer, with a role similar to that of procurators fiscal in Scotland, should be involved in authorising the detention of terrorist suspects for as long as seven days.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Scott queries Customs' methods in Matrix case
DOC.TEXT: The role of Customs and Excise in investigating alleged breaches of export regulations in the Matrix Churchill case was challenged yesterday by Lord Justice Scott. The judge questioned whether Customs had gained a sufficiently 'rounded picture' of the facts of the case before prosecuting three businessmen for illegally exporting defence-related machine tools to Iraq. He was speaking after taking oral evidence from Mr Peter Wiltshire, senior investigating officer in the Matrix Churchill case. Mr Wiltshire told the inquiry that he and Customs lawyers prepared their prosecution without taking statements from Whitehall officials directly involved in the licensing arrangements for Matrix Churchill exports. He also admitted that Customs either ignored or delayed circulating some intelligence reports relevant to the case that had been provided by MI6. These reports included details about the extent to which Matrix Churchill businessmen had been supplying information to the intelligence services. Mr Wiltshire said that he had gathered evidence that the Matrix Churchill businessmen had deceived Department of Trade and Industry licensing officials about the nature of the machine tools they were exporting. But the judge said Customs had the responsibility to fully test the defence case - that the machine tools had been exported with the tacit agreement of the government. The judge asked Mr Wiltshire: 'If the truth was that the DTI didn't mind . . . shouldn't you have investigated the background to see whether this was likely to be the case?' Mr Wiltshire said a trawl of official papers convinced him that no one in government 'really knew' what Matrix Churchill was up to. The hearing continues today.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Railtrack warns of cut in subsidies
DOC.BYLINE: By ROLAND RUDD and PAUL BETTS
DOC.TEXT: Private operators running trains will be forced to make big efficiency gains as subsidies are reduced, a director of Railtrack, the state-owned company set up to take over responsibility for British Rail's track and signalling, will warn today. Although the government has promised to increase subsidies in line with higher track charges, Sir Christopher Foster, a Railtrack director, says the operators' ability to make efficiency gains will reduce the need for big rail subsidies. In a speech to be delivered today to the University of Leeds, Sir Christopher will say that a commitment by the government to provide a subsidy to sustain rail services 'is not the same as saying that the current level of real subsidy should be maintained'. He believes that after the first year the government will reduce the Pounds 930m annual subsidy as the new train operators will be expected to make improvements to BR's 'old-established working practices'. Sir Christopher, who helped shape railway privatisation as a special adviser to the Department of Transport, says some of the potential entrants have put forward ideas on how to improve working practices. He believes railway timetables - which at present take BR up to 18 months to change - and scheduling of trains could be radically altered. He says this could save private operators significant amounts of money. He says that in the long term rolling stock companies, which are to be sold off separately, may find the government cutting the subsidy. Sir Christopher adds that it would not be in the taxpayers' interest if companies bidding for the rolling stock companies did not think that the government was planning to cut back demand through reduced subsidy. While the government's plan is to open up rail franchises to competition, Sir Christopher confirms that it is likely to be controlled in the short-term. Ministers are anxious to avoid the open competition triggered by bus privatisation, where fierce rivalry erupted on city-centre routes, clogging traffic and leading to a poorer service. Sir Christopher says that in the long term rail operators wanting to run trains on lucrative routes may have to pay the franchisee a fee towards the operation of unremunerative services. Balfour Beatty Civil Engineering yesterday won the Pounds 60m main contract to build the underground stations and tunnels for the Heathrow Express project, Paul Betts writes. The Pounds 300m joint project by BAA, the privatised airports group, and BR is to construct an express rail link between Heathrow and the centre of London. The service, scheduled to start operating in December 1997, will mean that the world's busiest international airport can be reached from Paddington Station in 16 minutes.
DOC.IN: P3743 Railroad Equipment. P4011 Railroads, Line-Haul Operating.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Security fears revived at vital strategic target
DOC.BYLINE: By NEIL BUCKLEY and RICHARD DONKIN
DOC.TEXT: Like the City of London, which has been struck by two IRA attacks in the past two years, Heathrow airport is an important target both economically and symbolically. It is the world's busiest international airport, handling more than 42m passengers a year, and is one of the UK's most important assets. It handles 40 per cent of all passenger traffic through UK airports, while Heathrow's World Cargo Centre is second only to the port of Dover in terms of the value of goods handled, with the equivalent of Pounds 34bn in visible trade. Heathrow is a significant employer - 50,000 people work at the airport, including 1,400 security staff, and an estimated 20,000 local jobs exist as a direct result of airport activity. Eighty different airlines use the airport, serving more than 200 destinations, with more than 370,000 aircraft movements a year. Closure of Heathrow for a whole day, for example as the result of terrorist action, could ground about 1,000 flights leaving up to 100,000 passengers stranded. Repeated closures that damaged its reputation for reliability could cost the airport hundreds of millions of pounds in lost business. Heathrow is also the centre of a thriving local hotel and conference industry, with 20 hotels offering about 5,000 beds in the immediate vicinity. The incident last night was the first mortar attack on mainland Britain since the IRA used home-made firing tubes to bomb a cabinet meeting in Downing Street in February 1991. Previous mortars have consisted of a 9in-diameter, 3ft-long steel tube. The apparently improvised weapon used last night has an even longer firing tube for greater accuracy and range. In the past the weapons have been used most effectively at ranges of between 400m and 500m. While two bombs landed on the runway without detonating, their firing point in the car park of the Excelsior Hotel would have brought a number of sensitive targets within range. One potential target from this position is the traffic tunnel under the runway that acts as the main thoroughfare into the terminal areas. Security within the airport perimeter fence was stepped up during the 1970s due to the IRA threat and again in 1986 when police began carrying machine guns in the airport lounges after terrorist attacks at Vienna and Rome airports. The Excelsior Hotel, sited on a public road north of the airport, does not enjoy the protection afforded inside the fence.
DOC.IN: P9229 Public Order and Safety, NEC. P4581 Airports, Flying Fields, and Services.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Wider financial regulatory net urged
DOC.TEXT: The sale of savings products such as Tessas, which were seen as alternatives to investment products, should be included in the retail financial services regulatory regime, a Standard Life executive told MPs yesterday. Mr Jim Stretton, the life insurance company's deputy managing director, told the cross-party Commons treasury committee inquiry into financial regulation that the rules should cover all products which seemed to be in competition with each other. These included some of the building societies' savings vehicles, which customers saw as quite similar to unit trusts. Mr Stretton again signalled that Standard Life was likely to join the Personal Investment Authority, the new watchdog to protect private investors, in spite of the company's preference for a single-tier statutory regulator. He resigned from the PIA board because most of its members would not come from the financial services industry so, he said, it would not be real self-regulation. He expressed some sympathy for proposals by Mr George Greener, chairman of Allied Dunbar and Eagle Star, for a single regulator in which an executive committee of people working in financial services was supervised by a board of public interest directors. He made it clear, however, that he did not believe there was enough common ground among the PIA's opponents to prevent the watchdog becoming operational in the summer.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / NUM in ballot on new structure
DOC.TEXT: The National Union of Mineworkers yesterday started balloting its Yorkshire members over merger plans which, if defeated, would spell the end for the union's structure. A close vote could even bring into question Mr Arthur Scargill's presidency, although those campaigning against the executive admitted yesterday that such an outcome was unlikely. The merger vote has been brought to a head because the NUM, which had 245,000 members in 1982, has about 8,000 members, nearly 6,000 of whom work in the Yorkshire area. This has led to rationalisation plans including the takeover of the Yorkshire area's Pounds 5.8m assets to help ease the union's financial crisis. A ballot is necessary to achieve the merger because of the NUM's federal structure. Mr John Walsh, agent and assistant general secretary of the Yorkshire area, dismissed in January but still in post pending an appeal, has said that he has been victimised for campaigning against the transfer, saying it will be detrimental to the union. Mr Walsh believes the union's national headquarters in Sheffield is virtually penniless. He said: 'I think it will be almost down to the reserve fund by now and that can only be used to back up the pension schemes. It has fixed assets probably of about Pounds 2m but it can't sell the building because nobody wants it.' The NUM executive has said in a letter to Yorkshire members that a merger will avoid an increase in contributions and save the area and the national union Pounds 200,000 in administrative costs alone.
DOC.IN: P8631 Labor Organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Search for peace faces long hard haul: Early hopes for an Ulster settlement are bogged down in political diversions
DOC.BYLINE: By DAVID OWEN and MICHAEL CASSELL
DOC.TEXT: British and Irish ministers will meet in London today anxious to demonstrate publicly that there will be no slacking in the search for peace in Northern Ireland. Privately, however, they concede they may face a long hard haul. The window of opportunity, opened with December's historic Downing Street declaration, appears to be creaking shut. The early hopes of imminent peace have become bogged down in political diversions which threaten to derail the two governments' initiative. For London and Dublin, the challenge is to keep the show on the road, to build on the genuine consensus which now exists between the two governments and to insist that their broader, bolder objectives will not be sidetracked by sub-plots. It is not going to be easy. The wave of mass killings last autumn, which gave impetus to intensified Anglo-Irish efforts to forge a durable settlement, has subsided, lowering the sense of urgency which underpinned a renewed readiness among the province's political parties to compromise. On the political front, the European elections beckon. As a result, the province's main political parties - headed by the Ulster Unionists (mindful of the need to protect their flank against the Rev Ian Paisley's hardline Democratic Unionists) - are already adopting a markedly more aggressive tone in discussing the prospects for a settlement. It is the season for retreating into entrenched positions. London has all but abandoned hope of reaching the stage where round-table talks between Ulster's main non-violent parties and the two governments can be resurrected until the elections are out of the way. In Dublin there is also, in the words of one Northern Ireland Office official, 'an acute awareness of the Ulster calendar'. In addition, the lengthening silence from Sinn Fein is increasingly being seen in both capitals as the republican movement's way of saying no to the declaration. A surprise acceptance has not been completely ruled out and any positive initiative by republican leaders could produce another twist in the political game now being played out. But few expect anything from Sinn Fein which will enable any significant headway to be made this side of Euro-polling day on June 9. Not surprisingly, both governments are accordingly playing down expectations for today's session. All the more so since attention is expected to focus on strand two of the three-stranded process: relations between Dublin and the north. This, by common consent, is the most difficult - or as one participant puts it, the most intellectually challenging - circle the talks process will have to square. As Lord Fitt, the former leader of the Catholic Social Democratic and Labour party, told his fellow peers last week: 'It is strand two that will cause all the difficulties. It has done so in the past and will undoubtedly do the same again in the future.' Today's meeting will take stock of the position, in effect already done at last weekend's meeting in Dublin between Sir Patrick Mayhew, Northern Ireland Secretary, and Mr Dick Spring, Irish Foreign minister. It will also discuss progress made by the liaison committee, set up after last month's so-called Twickenham summit between Mr John Major, the prime minister, and Mr Albert Reynolds, his Irish counterpart, in reaching a common position on the way ahead. But it is thought too early for significant progress to have been made, making it difficult to publicly demonstrate that the initiative is gathering momentum. Today's meeting will not attract the fanfare which surrounded the Downing Street declaration. But, although peace is apparently as elusive as ever, the intervening two months has done nothing to undermine the quiet determination in London and Dublin to finish what they started in September.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs. P9199 General Government, NEC. P8651 Political Organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Merseyside told to rethink EU bid
DOC.BYLINE: By IAN HAMILTON FAZEY, Northern Correspondent
DOC.TEXT: The European Commission in Brussels has rejected government proposals for spending Pounds 690m of EU money to revive Merseyside's flagging regional economy. The commission argues that the plans, submitted late last year and calling for about half the money to go into training, concentrate too much on solutions which have already failed and show policies for obtaining EU funds rather than regenerating the area. Brussels officials have told civil servants and Merseyside political leaders to rethink their strategy to give a bigger role to the private sector, which had complained about lack of involvement, and to concentrate on five 'growth drivers' - human resources, cultural industries, large industries, knowledge-based business, and small and medium-sized companies. The five-year 'Objective 1' status money offers funds to areas which has a gross domestic product per person under 75 per cent of the EU average. Rejection of the plans was welcomed by Mr Alan Arthur, chairman of coatings business King and Fowler and organiser of a 500-company local private-sector pressure group backed by the Confederation of British Industry. He said: 'Business people need to be able to use this opportunity. So far it has looked like only benefiting every advisory body and consultant who was ever born.'
DOC.IN: P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Proposals issued for venture trusts
DOC.TEXT: Investors in the venture capital trusts, announced in the November Budget, will be allowed tax relief on up to Pounds 100,000 a year, under proposals in a government consultative document published yesterday. The document suggests the trusts should be taxed and structured in a broadly similar way to investment trusts. It proposes that 80 per cent of trust assets should be in unlisted trading companies. Not more than 15 per cent of the assets should be in any one company or group of companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / World Trade News: US-Japan trade dispute defused
DOC.TEXT: The dispute over US access to the Japanese cellular phone market - at the centre of Washington's threats of trade sanctions - appeared to have been defused yesterday. The Japanese group IDO said it had reached a broad agreement with Motorola to expand the US company's cellular phone network, writes Paul Abrahams in Tokyo. Motorola has been trying for almost a decade to become a significant force in the Japanese mobile phone market. IDO, partly owned by Toyota, said the two companies were near agreement over the timing and extent of the expansion of the Motorola network. The Japanese company is offering to add 159 relay stations for Motorola's car phones. Mr Arnold Brenner, Motorola's vice-president, who arrived in Tokyo yesterday to finalise the agreement, wants the expansion completed within 18 months. The Japanese group says it will take more than two years. Discussions over the allocation of radio frequencies also need to be concluded.
DOC.CN: JPZ Japan, Asia. USZ United States of America.
DOC.IN: P3663 Radio and TV Communications Equipment. P4812 Radiotelephone Communications.
DOC.TP: MKTS Foreign trade. COMP Strategic links Joint venture.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / World Trade News: Kantor hits back at EU critics
DOC.TEXT: Mr Mickey Kantor, the US trade representative, yesterday attacked the European Union for its criticism of the Clinton administration's Japan policy and invited it to take part in US-Japan talks. 'Europeans are always delighted when they can hold our coats and we go out to get our noses bloodied,' he told the Economic Strategy Institute. The US was ready to 'trilateralise or multilateralise' its talks with Japan, 'but we don't look for criticism from those who sit on the sidelines and don't get in the game'. He said he could not define the 'managed trade' the EU was accusing the US of adopting. He pointed sarcastically to 'voluntary restraint on cars and trucks at 16 per cent in Europe? That wouldn't be managed trade, would it?' The EU telecommunications procurement and broadcast directives also curbed imports, he said. 'Every time it's in their interest to engage in behaviour which is not opening their markets, that's justified.' On Japan, Mr Kantor said there had been 'interesting movement' in the dispute over cellular telephones. He was awaiting documents from Tokyo, he said, and implied the agreement would have the kind of 'quantitative indicators' the US insisted on in the broader trade framework talks. Japan had failed to honour its promise to stimulate its economy, he claimed. 'They adopted a tax rebate proposal for one year and then tried to figure out how to pay for it. The definition of a stimulus is that you stimulate your economy and you don't pay for it.' On other subjects, he said: The US would ask the new World Trade Organisation, the proposed Gatt successor, to adopt a multilateral version of the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act to prohibit bribery of foreign officials. The US would seek the adoption of fair labour standards. He was hopeful that the declining trend in US semiconductor sales in Japan had been reversed in the fourth quarter of last year, but would move swiftly if it had not. The US-EU audio visual dispute had to be dealt with 'industry-to-industry and then government-to-government'.
DOC.CN: USZ United States of America. JPZ Japan, Asia.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs. P48 Communications. P3663 Radio and TV Communications Equipment. P3674 Semiconductors and Related Devices.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / World Trade News: Japanese clear way for Jeep
DOC.TEXT: Japan is expected to clear the way today for the US vehicle manufacturer Chrysler to boost substantially its exports to Japan of Jeep Cherokee sports utility vehicles, in what appears to be part of a campaign to ease trade tensions. Chrysler said yesterday that it had been told at short notice that a vice-minister in the Transport Ministry would present the company with a 'type certificate' at a meeting in Detroit today. The certificate allows Chrysler's distributor in Japan to carry out road-worthiness inspections of Cherokees rather than having to submit each vehicle for certification by the Transport Ministry. US car manufacturers have long complained that the ministry inspections are an important non-tariff trade barrier. Chrysler, which was told some time ago that it was likely to get a type certificate, plans to boost its Japanese sales of Cherokees from 4,000 a year to 10,000. However, a spokeswoman said yesterday that Japan still had a long way to go to open up its vehicle market.
DOC.IN: P3711 Motor Vehicles and Car Bodies. P5012 Automobiles and Other Motor Vehicles.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / World Trade News: Hyundai plans capacity boost - Geneva Motor Show
DOC.TEXT: South Korea's leading carmaker, Hyundai, is planning to increase capacity by 60 per cent to 2m units by the year 2000, Mr Se Yung Chung, chairman, said yesterday. Current global production capacity was 1.25m units, 1.15m in Korea and 100,000 overseas, he told The Economist motor conference in Geneva. The group produced 960,000 vehicles last year with domestic sales of 620,000 and exports of 350,000. It controls close to half the domestic market. Mr Chung said Hyundai was planning to build more foreign production sites to reinforce its presence in overseas markets. 'We envision manufacturing operations in North America, Europe, south-east Asia and in the Middle East.' The company also intended to shift the emphasis in its new car development programme 'away from smaller passenger cars to put more weight on the development of higher value-added vehicles'. Production capacity would rise by 110,000 vehicles this year and construction had just begun on a bus and heavy duty truck plant in Chonju. The entire South Korean motor industry has embarked on a period of rapid expansion of capacity and is moving quickly to expand its presence in foreign markets. Hyundai is seeking to cut its dependence on Mitsubishi of Japan for engine technology. Mr Chung said that 'in the not too distant future all Hyundai vehicles will be equipped with engines and transmissions of Hyundai's proprietary design'. The company was seeking 'technological independence' so that its survival could not be challenged.
DOC.IN: P3711 Motor Vehicles and Car Bodies. P3714 Motor Vehicle Parts and Accessories.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / World Trade News: Suzuki to export cars from India - Geneva Motor Show
DOC.TEXT: Suzuki, the Japanese carmaker, is to begin exporting cars to west Europe from India. Later this year it will launch in Europe its Alto minicar produced by Maruti Udyog, its Indian production base. The car was launched last summer in India, where it is sold as the Maruti Zen. The Alto is the first model Suzuki has developed at an overseas production base for introduction in overseas markets. Maruti Udyog is India's largest car manufacturer and was the first large-scale Japanese-Indian joint venture. It is 50/50 owned by Suzuki and the Indian government. Maruti is expanding its production capacity from 130,000 vehicles a year at present to 200,000 by the end of the year in order to expand sales in both the domestic and export markets. This spring it will produce its one millionth vehicle since it began production in 1983 under India's 'people's car plan'. It controls 70 per cent of the Indian car market. Suzuki's move to begin supplying the European market from India comes at a time when it is has run into serious problems with its production plant in Spain, where it assembles small four-wheel-drive sports/utility vehicles, the Vitara and the SJ series. Santana Motor, its 82 per cent owned Spanish subsidiary has recently applied for protection from creditors under pressure of mounting losses, and Suzuki has threatened to close the plant unless it receives state aid. Suzuki also has an assembly plant in Hungary, from which it will export cars to west Europe next month.
DOC.CN: INZ India, Asia. ESZ Spain, EC. HUZ Hungary, East Europe.
DOC.IN: P5012 Automobiles and Other Motor Vehicles. P3711 Motor Vehicles and Car Bodies.
