DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / World Trade News: Gatt seeks to expand its HQ in Geneva
DOC.TEXT: High-level negotiations are taking place between the Swiss government and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade on practical and financial arrangements for Gatt's change of status next year to a fully-fledged World Trade Organisation. Office accommodation, meeting facilities, parking and the issue of diplomatic status for senior officials top Gatt's list of concerns. Trade officials warned that if satisfactory arrangements were not made the WTO could look for another home. 'Negotiations are going fairly well. The Swiss recognise the need to keep the WTO in town,' one official said yesterday. Competition for international agencies, including financial inducements, has intensified in recent years, partly for reasons of prestige but also because of the boost to the local economy. International organisations and diplomats account for 9 per cent of employment in Geneva and bring in SFr1.5bn (Pounds 702m) a year to the Swiss city. Mr Arthur Dunkel, former Gatt director-general and now chairman of a new private foundation to promote Geneva as an international centre, is said to be playing a behind-the-scenes role in the negotiations. Office accommodation is one key factor. The size of the WTO's staff is certain to be much larger than the 450 now employed by Gatt. Gatt wants to expand into the whole of its present lakeside building, part of which is now occupied by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Though the UNHCR is due to move into purpose-built offices this September, these were planned when the agency was much smaller and there is now not enough room for all 800 headquarters employees. Berne has, however, already approved SFr34m to build a new WTO council room. The present one can no longer accommodate delegates from all Gatt's 116 member nations plus observers.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / World Trade News: US seeks 'fairer' export control - A look at proposals to lift cold war-based curbs on trade
DOC.TEXT: From its inception, the administration of President Bill Clinton has made business its business - in particular high -technology business - and competitiveness has been given the highest priority. Despite budget stringency, millions of dollars are flowing into public-private technology partnerships, Mr Clinton's people fought their labour and liberal allies to clinch the North American Free Trade Agreement and the Uruguay Round and officials roam the world hawking contracts for US companies. There has, however, been one big disappointment for business. With the end of the cold war, exporters had high hopes that Mr Clinton would lighten one of their heaviest burdens: export controls on dual-use and high-technology products. Last month Mr Clinton announced proposals for a much-delayed Export Administration Act, the law governing export controls, and called for far-reaching licensing liberalisation. The aim has shifted from denying products to communist nations to controlling the spread of weapons of mass destruction. Mr Clinton's proposal calls for strengthening the role of the US Commerce Department in the approval process. It seeks a rigorous evaluation of controls, including their economic impact, before they are imposed; the lifting of old controls that are clearly ineffectual; and simplification of the licensing process, which would result in an answer to the most controversial applications within 90 days. It would introduce the concept of 'unfair impact', allowing industry to petition for removal of controls based on whether similar products might be available from other suppliers abroad, on competitive disadvantage or ineffectiveness of the control. Business reaction to these proposals have ranged from unimpressed to hostile. Many computer companies say that no unilateral controls are necessary because computers have been found to do nothing to aid weapons proliferation. Mr Howard Lewis, vice-president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said that without a total overhaul licensing could cost the US Dollars 30bn (Pounds 20.5bn) a year in exports by the mid-1990s. But the president's plan 'would create a system of unilateral controls loosely co-ordinated with other countries. It would not establish clear authority and accountability for running the system. And it would not do enough to tell US companies clearly what, and to whom, not to export', he said. Mr Peter McCloskey, president of the Electronic Industries Association, said the proposed EAA was 'woefully inadequate'. 'Rapidly changing product life cycles necessitate an export control system that can react quickly and focus only on those technologies that are critical for the development of weapons of mass destruction,' he said. Industry has taken its case to Congress where favoured legislation, sponsored by Delaware Senator William Roth and Minnesota Congressman James Oberstar, is to be written by a House banking committee today. This bill would do away with all national security controls imposed unilaterally on the grounds that critical technologies can best be curbed by co-operation between supplier countries. It would strengthen international export controls by extending preferential treatment to countries which agree to abide by common standards of licensing and enforcement. It wants business input in multilateral negotiations to establish stricter controls on a smaller list of strategic commodities. 'Excessively long control lists only spur resistance from allies and ultimately hinder the effectiveness of control regimes,' said the Coalition for Fundamental Reform of the Export Control System. While business is pushing for a multilateral solution, the US and its allies in the Co-ordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls are meeting in Paris this week to wind up the organisation's affairs. CoCom is to go out of business on March 31, and with no great common enemy to unite them, the allies are far from agreeing a successor organisation. Russia is to join the new group, which will focus on controls of dual-use goods and conventional arms to outlaw regimes such as Iran, Iraq, and North Korea. In the absence of agreement, the US has been expected to propose continuation of the current control lists. Meanwhile, Congress must either hope that one day an effective multilateral regime will be in place, muddle along with sporadic unilateral controls which disadvantage US industry or lift all export licensing requirements except for those products most egregiously dangerous.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs. P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.
DOC.TP: MKTS Foreign trade. CMMT Comment Analysis.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Judge rules out claim by Mirror
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ruled that one of the late Robert Maxwell's companies had no right to a claim against the New York Daily News, the tabloid newspaper owned by Maxwell when he died, Reuter reports from New York. The ruling, made on Tuesday and released yesterday, settled the final dispute in the newspaper's bankruptcy that came shortly after Maxwell died in November 1991. Mirror Group Newspapers claimed the paper stole Dollars 92m (Pounds 63m) from the group, saying Maxwell and his son, Kevin, took the money to run the Daily News. The US bankruptcy judge denied the Mirror claim, saying the Maxwells lied to the tabloid's directors and their actions hurt the Daily News as well as the Mirror Group. The judge said the father and son engaged in an 'elaborate ruse', concealing the source of money to the newspaper and planned to strip the tabloid of even more money at a time when its ability to publish was in jeopardy.
DOC.CO: New York Daily News. Mirror Group Newspapers.
DOC.IN: P9211 Courts.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Special counsel fails to win Whitewater accord
DOC.TEXT: Mr Robert Fiske, the independent counsel, and senior Republicans yesterday failed in their first attempt to negotiate a compromise under which Congress could hold hearings into the Whitewater affair. Both Senator Al D'Amato from New York and Sen William Cohen from Maine remained hopeful some resolution could be reached. Sen Cohen spoke of delaying a congressional investigation and of not granting immunity from prosecution to witnesses, if either made Mr Fiske's task easier. The special counsel did not budge from his objection that hearings on Capitol Hill could jeopardise the integrity of his own investigations. But he conceded he could not stop Congress calling hearings. He also implied he could work around them if they were confined to the question of meetings between White House and regulatory officials on the status of Madison Guaranty, the Arkansas savings bank at the heart of the Whitewater affair. He added he was completely satisfied with White House co-operation to date. The failed Arkansas savings and loan institution is at the centre of the Whitewater allegations that Mr and Mrs Clinton engaged in improper financial dealings in the 1980s. The Democratic leadership on Capitol Hill seemed more determined than ever yesterday to frustrate Republican wishes. Sen George Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said the Republicans wanted to stage 'a political circus' that would 'throw up a lot of dust and embarrass the president'. Mr Fiske, Senator Mitchell said, 'is independent, is a Republican, was selected at the request of Republicans and it's very clear, as he says, you can't have both a congressional investigation and an independent investigation'. Press advice on the issue was mixed yesterday. The New York Times urged a compromise that would give Mr Fiske 'a head start, probably measured in weeks' before Congress got in on the act. The Wall Street Journal, as ever virulently anti-Clinton, headlined its comment yesterday: 'The Fiske Cover-up.' It pretty much demanded fully-fledged hearings. The president's press spokeswoman was forced to deny rumours in the New York markets that Mr Roger Altman, the deputy Treasury secretary, was about to resign because he had participated in the SL meetings. He is among 10 officials under subpoena to testify in front of the federal grand jury convened by Mr Fiske. Mr Clinton said yesterday he had advised the 10 to be 'very open' and tell everything they knew. Several news organisations continued to report on the alleged shredding by the Rose Law Firm of Little Rock, where Mrs Hillary Clinton was a part ner, of documents purportedly bearing the name of Vincent Foster, the deputy White House legal counsel who com-mitted suicide last summer.
DOC.IN: P6552 Subdividers and Developers, Ex Cemeteries. P8111 Legal Services.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Mexican interest rates rise
DOC.TEXT: Mexico's interest rates rose for the second week running yesterday after further volatility in the peso/dollar exchange rate, writes Damian Fraser in Mexico City. Rates on short-term government paper rose to 9.3 per cent, up 0.29 percentage points from last week. The rise in rates came as the 48-hour peso/dollar buy rate closed at 3.26 after weakening to 3.30. The peso has lost some 5 per cent of its value in a month, and has been close to its central bank limit of 3.357. Currency traders blame the peso's weakness on low economic growth, mounting political uncertainty in Mexico, and higher interest rates in the US. The low growth has encouraged the government - until the last two weeks - to push interest rates down quickly. The government's revised figures show growth fell 0.8 per cent in the third quarter last year, and 0.1 per cent in the fourth quarter.
DOC.IN: P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Birds still rule Antigua roost
DOC.TEXT: The 25-year domination of Antiguan politics by the Bird family will continue with the victory of the incumbent Labour Party in last Tuesday's general election. Mr Lester Bird, the Labour leader, is to be sworn in as prime minister, succeeding his 84-year-old father, Mr Vere Bird Sr, who has resigned. Preliminary results have given the Labour Party 11 of the 17 seats in the assembly. The opposition United Progressive Party, which had one seat in the previous parliament, took five, with the lone seat on the island of Barbuda going to the People's Movement. The campaign was dominated by charges from the opposition that the Labour government's long control of the government had led to endemic corruption, with the islands, whose economy is based on tourism, being used for drug smuggling and money laundering. Mr Lester Bird consistently rejected the charges during the campaign, but promised to take a hard line against any impropriety in the government. The new prime minister's early tasks will include a decision on the role, if any, which his elder brother, Mr Vere Bird Jr, will play in politics. Mr Bird Jr, who won a seat, was the central figure in a judicial inquiry four years ago, in which it was alleged that he had used his office as a government minister to facilitate the transhipment of Israeli arms to Colombian drug cartels.
DOC.IN: P8651 Political Organizations. P9199 General Government, NEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Clinton launches jobs plans
DOC.TEXT: President Bill Clinton yesterday unveiled his plans to overhaul the US unemployment system to retrain unemployed workers and move them back into new jobs. The plan would provide longer unemployment benefits for people who are undertaking retraining, as well as laid-off workers who decided to open their own businesses. Mr Clinton also promised to bring six separate state and federal benefit, counselling and training programmes under a single roof. 'The first element of the plan is to create one-stop shopping so workers can go to one office and get the counselling and assistance they need,' Mr Clinton said at a White House ceremony to launch the plan yesterday afternoon. The initiative, which is expected to face considerable modification in Congress, is likely to be presented by the administration at next week's Group of Seven jobs conference in Detroit as a centrepiece of efforts the US is making to improve employment prospects. While the US has generated far more jobs than the less flexible European economies over the past decade, European governments have often suggested that the US system conceals the real level of joblessness by simply cutting off unemployment benefits after a relatively short period. They have also criticised the inadequacy of US training schemes. US officials this week have insisted that they want to move beyond that 1980s argument, insisting that each of the G7 countries can learn from the others. 'We are still going to say to them in Europe that part of their problem stems from the fact that their labour markets are very inflexible. . . . But one of the places where we are going to learn the most is on training and moving people from school to work, and we are going to learn a lot from the Europeans on that,' said Mr Lewis Alexander, chief economist at the US Commerce Department. The plan put forward by Mr Clinton yesterday would provide benefits to unemployed workers for up to two years of training, at a cost, when it is fully phased in, of about Dollars 3bn (Pounds 2bn) a year. US unemployment benefits usually run out after 26 weeks, although for much of the last three years Congress has voted to extend benefits for between seven and 33 additional weeks. Mr Clinton said yesterday that the old unemployment benefits system was designed to give people 'enough to live on until their old jobs came back because most jobs were lost in ordinary cyclical recessions'. That system was no longer adequate in an economy where three out of four workers laid off last year expected never to get their old jobs back, he said, and where the average US worker would change jobs seven or eight times in a lifetime.
DOC.IN: P9441 Administration of Social and Manpower Programs. P8331 Job Training and Related Services.
DOC.TP: ECON Employment unemployment. GOVT Government News.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / IADB members raise - and lower - the stakes: A look at a capital-boosting deal
DOC.TEXT: The US and its Latin American partners have agreed to reduce their stake in the Inter-American Development Bank as part of an accord to boost the bank's capital by Dollars 40bn (Pounds 27bn). The agreement, which will reduce the US shareholding in the bank to around 30 per cent from 34.6 per cent, also envisages the bank lifting its current bar on lending to the private sector. The capital increase, if details are finalised as expected at the bank's annual meeting in Guadalajara, Mexico, next month, would allow the bank's non-regional members - particularly Japan and Germany - to expand their small stakes in the institution. Japan, which currently holds only 1.08 per cent of the bank's capital, has been pressing for an expansion in its stake to reflect its financial support for US initiatives in Latin America. The agreement is also expected to provide Japan with an executive director on the board, which will be thus expanded to 13 members. As part of the accord, the borrowing members of the bank from Latin America and the Caribbean will reduce their combined stake from 53.8 per cent to a fraction over 50 per cent. The Dollars 40bn increase should allow the bank to continue with a lending programme of Dollars 7bn-Dollars 8bn a year for an indefinite period. Only 2.5 per cent of the increase will be paid in by shareholders, the rest being callable capital against which the bank will be able borrow in capital markets. The increase in the stake of the non-regional shareholders will reduce considerably the budget implications for the US, which is currently Dollars 847m in arrears in its commitments to international institutions. The bank's lending to the private sector will be limited to infrastructure projects, with a ceiling probably of 5 per cent - Dollars 350m to Dollars 400m a year. The bank will only lend where the private sector is also providing finance, and to a maximum 25 per cent of total lending. Under the accord, the bank will double the proportion of its lending going to so-called social sectors, such as primary health and education which are now considered the central issue for the region's development. Some 50 per cent of transactions (40 per cent by value of lending) will be directed to these areas. The bank will also direct lending for the first time to improve the quality of government - for instance, enhancing the region's judicial systems. Mr Enrique Iglesias, the bank's president, said the capital replenishment accord was 'more than a capital increase. It's a redefinition of bank policy to better respond to Latin America's problems.' However, there was still much to do before the increase was finally agreed. This includes completing discussions about the bank's soft-loan window, the Fund for Special Operations, and resolving differences over whether another seat on the board is required for the bank's Latin American members as Chile, especially, is seeking. However, a US Treasury official was optimistic that the issues could be resolved by the Guadalajara meeting and remarked on the 'positive manner' in which the discussions had been held.
DOC.CN: USZ United States of America. JPZ Japan, Asia. MXZ Mexico. CLZ Chile, South America.
DOC.IN: P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Mexico rates up as peso weakens
DOC.TEXT: Mexico's interest rates rose for the second consecutive week yesterday after further volatility in the peso/dollar exchange rate. Rates on short-term government paper rose to 9.3 per cent, an increase of 29 basis points from last week. The rise in rates came as the 48-hour peso/dollar buy rate at one point weakened to 3.30 yesterday morning, although it strengthened to 3.2750 at noon. The peso has lost some 5 per cent in a month, and has been close to its central bank limit of 3.357. Currency traders blame the peso's weakness on low economic growth, mounting political uncertainty in Mexico, and higher interest rates in the US. The low growth has encouraged the government - until the last two weeks - to push interest rates down quickly. The government's revised figures show growth fell 0.8 per cent in the third quarter last year, and 0.1 per cent in the fourth quarter. But as US interest rates have risen, the spread between Mexican and US returns reached historic lows. This has sharply cut the attraction of Mexican government paper to foreign investors, according to Mr Joge Mariscal of Goldman Sachs, the private US investment bank. Other investors blame the weak currency on the uncertain political landscape, especially the rumoured presidential ambitions of Mr Manuel Camacho, the peace envoy to the troubled southern state of Chiapas. 'If Camacho registers then there will be so much uncertainty that the exchange rate may not hold within its band,' said a leading money market trader in Mexico City. A number of opposition political parties could replace their existing presidential candidate with Mr Camacho up to a month before August's election. Aides to Mr Camacho make it clear he has not ruled out running for the presidency. His eventual decision may depend on support for Mr Luis Donaldo Colosio, the candidate of the governing party, in opinion polls.
DOC.IN: P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Shekel curbs to go if inflation rate is reduced
DOC.BYLINE: By PETER NORMAN and JULIAN OZANNE
DOC.TEXT: Israel will make its currency, the shekel, fully convertible but only after its inflation rate has moved much closer to those of its leading trading partners, Mr Jacob Frenkel, governor of Israel's central bank, said. He also said he wanted further measures to liberalise the economy before allowing Israelis and foreigners complete freedom to buy and sell the currency. However, Mr Frenkel made clear in an interview that the bank would move to full convertibility as soon as possible but the move would have to be sustainable and not subject to setbacks. Israel has progressively liberalised its once strictly controlled foreign exchange and money markets since the middle of the 1980s as part of a policy of opening its economy to the outside world. But while trading in the shekel for trade and business purposes is practically free of regulation, Israeli residents still face restrictions on opening bank accounts and buying property abroad. Mr Frenkel said because of Israel's geo-political position, 'there is a lot of vulnerability' in the economy. Full convertibility could expose Israel's economy to 'very huge swings' of capital in and out of the country. The experience of former communist countries that have rapidly made their currencies convertible showed that premature action in this area was counter-productive and inevitably forced a retreat, Mr Frenkel said. Israel's inflation rate - currently about 10 per cent - would have to be much closer to the 2 or 3 per cent inflation rates of the big industrialised countries. This would be a precondition for making the exchange rate of the shekel more stable. Israel has set an 8 per cent inflation target this year and hopes to achieve further staged reductions in inflation in the years ahead. Consistent with its inflation target, the Bank of Israel pursues a 'crawling band' exchange rate policy that envisages a 6 per cent depreciation of the shekel's value against the currencies of its main trading partners this year. Mr Frenkel said the bank was waiting to see the impact of new housing and land policies on inflation but would not hesitate to raise interest rates further if necessary to achieve the 8 per cent target for this year. 'We will not give any weight to questions of controversy in the conduct of interest rate or monetary policy. It would be a mistake,' he said.
DOC.IN: P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Japanese corruption probe widened
DOC.TEXT: Japanese public prosecutors yesterday widened their investigation into alleged corruption when they raided more than 30 homes and offices of politicians and construction company executives, Paul Abrahams writes from Tokyo. The raids followed a request by prosecutors earlier this week for the parliamentary immunity of Mr Kishiro Nakamura, a former Liberal Democratic party construction minister, to be lifted so he could be arrested on charges of bribery. Mr Nakamura, whose home was among those raided, yesterday resigned from the LDP. A decision about whether his immunity should be lifted must be made by a full session of the lower house of parliament. It could give its consent today. If the request is successful, it would be the first time since 1967 that a Japanese lawmaker has been arrested while parliament was sitting. The prosecutors allege Mr Nakamura accepted a Y10m (Pounds 64,000) bribe on January 13 1992 from Mr Shinji Kiyoyama, a former vice-president of the construction company Kajima. Yesterday's raids covered the homes of Mr Rokuro Ishikawa, chairman of Kajima, Mr Akira Miyazaki, the group's president, as well as Kajima's head office. The home of Mr Tsuneo Aki, vice-president of Obayashi corporation, one of Japan's five biggest construction groups, was also raided. Rising long-term interest rates in Japan threaten to have an adverse impact on the economy, Mr Yasushi Mieno, governor of the country's central bank, said yesterday, following the decision on Tuesday by the Industrial Bank of Japan to raise its long-term prime-lending rate by 0.6 percentage points to 4.4 per cent. He said the Bank of Japan had no intention of intervening.
DOC.IN: P9199 General Government, NEC. P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy. P1629 Heavy Construction, NEC. P1542 Nonresidential Construction, NEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Japan's consumers spurn rice fit for an emperor
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito has consented to eat it. Mr Eijiro Hata, Japan's farm minister, tried it yesterday and found it 'tasty in its own way'. But a public suspicious of the foreign rice now on sale in the country prefers to queue for up to two hours for the more expensive domestic equivalent. As Mr Hata toured Tokyo stores to try to end panic buying of domestic rice, the Imperial Household Agency said it had bought samples of US, Chinese and Thai rice and the emperor had consented to eat the varieties mixed with domestic rice. Indeed, for general sale the government will require the blending of foreign and domestic rice, so consumers will not be in a position to discriminate against the imported crop. A first wave of buying began a few weeks ago after reports that only 30 per cent of the rice marketed would be domestic. The Uruguay Round of trade liberalisation talks, a poor rice crop due to typhoons and a cold summer have forced the government into covering the shortage with imports. Rumours of cigarette butts and rodents found in foreign rice exacerbated fears about the imported product, already suspected in Japan of being unsafe because of the pesticides and fungicides used. However, even the imported rice for blending has been delayed in reaching national retailers, and a second wave of buying has even spread to foreign rice. Long queues now form in front of supermarkets on the day they receive their rice supply from wholesalers. 'People are buying two to three times as much as they usually do,' says Mr Yoshiro Takahashi of Rice Data Bank, which provides information on rice distribution. He says some wholesalers and distributors are hoarding rice in the hope that the price will rise further. However, many of the older generation insist they would rather eat bread and noodles than imported rice. Some retailers say a number of consumers seem to be put off from eating rice due to the confusion. The Tokyo stock market has reacted to the current chaos in its own frenetic way. Bakery and flour mill stocks have surged during the past week in anticipation of a rise in bread consumption due to the rice shortage.
DOC.IN: P9641 Regulation of Agricultural Marketing. P5149 Groceries and Related Products, NEC.
DOC.TP: MKTS Foreign trade. TECH Safety Standards.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Police open fire on 'homeland' demonstrators
DOC.TEXT: Riot police fired at demonstrators in the South African black 'homeland' of Bophuthatswana for the second day running yesterday as a civil service strike paralysed the government of increasingly embattled homeland leader President Lucas Mangope. At least 32 people were wounded, witnesses said. The homeland government said a police officer was killed. President Mangope, who yesterday closed down the broadcasting service and sacked all of its staff, rejected a request from the Independent Electoral Commission to allow campaigning and polling for the April elections to take place in the homeland. Bophuthatswana said earlier this week it would not participate in these elections. As teargas drifted toward the government offices from the nearby University of Bophuthatswana, Finance Minister Ephraim Keikalame admitted candidly to journalists: 'It is not possible to have an effective functioning government under these circumstances.' Almost the whole of the public service appeared to be on strike, including essential services like hospitals, but telephones and electricity continued to function. The capital's main hospital complex was deserted by staff, with some patients lying unattended. Outside the university, pol-ice armoured vehicles roared up and down throughout the day, firing teargas cannisters and rubber bullets at students barricading the entrance gate. The rioting provoked a threat of direct South African intervention, with the Transitional Executive Council, the multi-party body overseeing government in the run-up to elections, saying it would give President Mangope a week 'to change his attitude' after which steps would be taken to force reincorporation.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Nigeria and Cameroon clash over oil-rich area
DOC.TEXT: Sabre-rattling and nationalist sentiment in Nigeria and Cameroon over a disputed oil-rich peninsula that forms their shared border disguise vital economic interests in the area as the governments of both countries face strident opposition from democracy campaigners and dissenting minority tribes. Nigeria has almost 10 times the population of its neighbour and for years the Bakassi peninsula has been mainly inhabited by Nigerians, many of them migrant fishermen. Although this area of south-eastern Nigeria produces 90 per cent of the nation's foreign earnings, the dozens of minority tribes in the region have been, on the government's own admission, neglected. Dispossession or pollution of their farming and fishing areas have not been offset by a share of the oil wealth, which has been invested in the north and west of Nigeria. Large investment in exploration deep offshore could make the region even wealthier in the next century. Bakassi also controls the seaway leading to Calabar, the nearest big Nigerian port and the site of a new Export Processing zone. As the Nigerian government prepares for its delayed constitutional conference, the eastern minorities are arguing for a better deal and more autonomy. The military regime suspects that talk of autonomy could lead to secession and the loss of massive oil wealth. Cameroon's largest and most vocal dissident political grouping, the opposition SDF party, has its stronghold near the border region. The mainly Anglophone region produces most of Cameroon's wealth and is home to more than 2m Nigerians. Bakassi was part of the British-governed southern Cameroons from the First World War until 1961 when the territory voted in a plebiscite to join the newly independent Cameroon. In 1975 at the Marua treaty Nigeria's Gen Yakubu Gowon re-affirmed Cameroon's claim to the area, allegedly to thank Cameroon for providing access to re-capture Calabar during the Biafran war. Nigeria's federal survey department published an atlas in 1978 signed by then head of state Gen Olusegun Obasanjo which clearly shows Bakassi to be in Cameroon. Squabbles over the boundary in the swamps led to a clash of troops in 1981 then the row subsided. But Bakassi became an international dispute early this year when Nigeria moved troops into the peninsula to counter alleged raids by Cameroonian gendarmes against Nigerian fishermen. Last month, Cameroon demanded the withdrawal of the troops from its territory and complained to the United Nations Security Council. After a skirmish on February 18 between rival military patrols in the peninsula, with reports of light casualties on both sides, Cameroon asked France for assistance under a bilateral defence pact. France sent two helicopters and 15 troops to the capital Yaounde, a day's drive from the border, at the same time as a senior diplomatic mission including President Francois Mitterrand's special adviser on Africa, Mr Bruno Delaye, to mediate between the two sides. Both Britain and France are advising that the dispute be resolved in bilateral talks, possibly with some assistance from the international court at The Hague, and both believe that a debate before the UN Security Council, of which France this month is chairman and Nigeria a temporary member, would be acrimonious.
DOC.CN: NGZ Nigeria, Africa. CMZ Cameroon, Africa.
DOC.IN: P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy. P1311 Crude Petroleum and Natural Gas. P9721 International Affairs.
DOC.TP: RES Natural resources. CMMT Comment Analysis.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Overheating to dominate congress
DOC.TEXT: China's parliament begins a two-week session today that is certain to be dominated by concerns over the country's overheating economy and inflation which exceeded 20 per cent in the big cities last year, writes Tony Walker. China's Premier Li Peng, in his 'work report', will call for a slowing of economic activity from 13 per cent last year to 9 per cent this year, but economists say that such a sharp reduction is unrealistic. Mr Li, who is beginning the second year of his second five-year term, will emphasise the need for political and social stability. He can be expected to give little quarter to international demands for greater political liberalisation. This National People's Congress, which will seek further to consolidate China's economic reforms, is being held in the shadow of the continuing row with Britain over Hong Kong and against a background of international concern about China's human rights behaviour. Mr Li will assail Britain over the breakdown of talks on Hong Kong's future, saying that London should assume 'full responsibility'. The NPC will deal with a modest legislative programme in contrast to last year.
DOC.IN: P9199 General Government, NEC. P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / HK reform bill faces tough debate
DOC.TEXT: The second and final stage of governor Chris Patten's democratic reforms for Hong Kong, containing many of the more controversial elements that failed to win Beijing's approval after 17 rounds of negotiations, was introduced into the colony's Legislative Council (LegCo) yesterday. The bill which, among other proposals, gives the colony's 2.7m-strong workforce a second vote through the creation of nine new functional constituencies (industry-based groupings) replacing corporate votes with votes cast by individual employees, is expected to have a stormy ride through LegCo even in the absence of a further outburst from China. While Beijing itself has already made clear that it views the move as a unilateral step by Britain and therefore one which brings to an end co-operation between the two over the future of Hong Kong, and has further said it will unwind representative bodies on resuming sovereignty, LegCo members are also lining up for battle. Some believe the proposals do not go far enough; others will push for a watered down version. However, with the bill designed to prepare the way for elections this year, there will also be pressure to move swiftly. Legislation would need to be enacted before LegCo's summer recess in July to allow the administration to put in place the practical preparations for the elections, the government said. The government believes the proposals will lead to fair and open elections, and that broadening the franchise will strengthen the credibility of the functional constituency system. However, Mr CM Leung, deputy secretary for constitutional affairs, conceded it was still in a state of evolution. 'The system is not perfect,' he said. If the bill is passed, all adults aged 18 or above and registered in the electoral roll will be able to cast votes in up to two categories: their geographical constituency and their functional constituency. Non-working groups such as housewives will be restricted to a single vote. In addition to introducing nine new functional constituencies, four existing professional groups will be expanded. By scrapping corporate voting - whereby one authorised person casts votes on behalf of his company - the government claims it will rid the colony of the problem of multiple voting, which occurs when one director controls a number of companies and hence a number of votes. The first-past-the-post voting system will be adopted for all bar three functional constituencies, where the preferential elimination system will be retained in view of their smaller franchises.
DOC.CN: CNZ China, Asia. HKZ Hong Kong, Asia.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs. P9199 General Government, NEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Dalai Lama attacks Beijing
DOC.TEXT: The Dalai Lama yesterday attacked China for paying 'lip service' to his attempts to negotiate on the future of Tibet and said Tibetans might have to adopt a new approach to their freedom struggle. The exiled leader's statement, issued from his home in Dharamsala, India, is likely to increase tension during this week's visit to Beijing by Mr Warren Christopher, US secretary of state. Tibet is among the human rights issues on which the US is demanding progress before China's most-favoured nation (MFN) trading status is renewed this year. The Dalai Lama said he had 'left no stone unturned' in seeking an agreement on the basis of a statement in 1979 by Mr Deng Xiaoping, China's leader, that 'except for independence of Tibet, all other questions can be negotiated'. But Beijing had repeatedly rejected his overtures. He said: 'I must now recognise that my approach has failed to produce any progress either for substantive negotiations or in contributing to the overall improvement of the situation in Tibet.' The Dalai Lama acknowledged that his failure to press for complete independence had disappointed many Tibetans. He said conditions in Tibet had worsened dramatically with increased suppression and marginalisation of Tibetans and the destruction of culture and the environment.
DOC.CN: CNZ China, Asia. INZ India, Asia.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Christopher's mission imperfect: A look at a difficult visit to Beijing by the US secretary of state
DOC.TEXT: Such is the fragile state of Sino-US relations and the high stakes involved that Mr Warren Christopher, the US secretary of state, arrives in Beijing tomorrow just a day after China's annual parliamentary session convenes. Normally, foreign envoys would be discouraged from visiting during this two-week period in early spring when 3,000 delegates to China's parliament gather in the Great Hall of the People, but Mr Christopher's is no ordinary mission. The US official, who has met his counterpart, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, three times since last year will try to engage the Chinese further on a range of issues, while at the same time warning them of the seriousness of the human rights issue. Judging by the recent spate of arrests of prominent Chinese dissidents, Mr Christopher faces significant difficulties in his efforts to persuade his hosts that such persistent harassment threatens renewal of China's preferential trading status in the US. More to the point, argument over human rights risks undermining the Clinton administration's attempts to broaden its links with Beijing that followed a decision last September to halt the 'downward spiral' in relations. Washington's Pacific strategy, based on enhancing the role of the Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation forum with China as a key partner, may also be jeopardised. Not least of the regional issues in which China and the US have a vital interest is that of trying to ensure that the simmering argument over North Korea's nuclear ambitions does not boil over in a way that might destabilise the Korean peninsula. A rupture over human rights could also threaten a booming commercial relationship that saw two-way trade exceed Dollars 40bn (Pounds 27.3bn) last year, with the balance heavily in China's favour. The World Bank estimates that 96 per cent of China's exports to the US are covered by preferential tariffs. Mr Christopher was understandably exasperated in remarks to reporters in Canberra this week when he observed that China was 'going in the wrong direction' on human rights. Indeed, he was reported to have even canvassed the possibility of abandoning his Beijing visit in protest at the recent arrests. Chinese officials remain confident, however, that in the end Mr Clinton will feel obliged to renew China's most favoured nation trading status. This calculation - American officials worry about China under-estimating the strength of US sentiment on human rights - may in part explain Beijing's playing 'hardball' on the eve of the visit. 'The Clinton administration will renew China's MFN status because of the pressure of different groups in the US who have a vested interest in China's enormous market,' said a senior Chinese adviser on US policy. 'However, from now until June, there will be a process of hard barg-aining.' A possible complication for Mr Christopher and Chinese leaders during their talks in the next few days is that, with parliament in session, no official will want to be seen adopting a quiescent attitude in what are certain to be difficult discussions. US officials should steel themselves for some sharp exchanges. The US has prepared carefully for the Christopher mission with several visits recently to Beijing by Mr John Shattuck, the assistant secretary of state for human rights. He spelled out American requirements for MFN renewal to meet the criteria of 'overall significant improvement' laid down by Mr Clinton. These include access to prisons for the International Committee of the Red Cross, an end to prison-made exports to the US, the further release of dissidents, human rights improvements in Tibet and steps toward making it easier for Chinese to emigrate. The US could hardly have done more to improve relations since its decision last September to 'engage' China. Apart from Mr Clinton's meetings in Seattle with President Jiang Zemin in November, a succession of senior administration officials have passed through Beijing, including Mr Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury secretary, and Mr Charles Freeman, an assistant secretary of defence. Indeed, defence co-operation is high on the agenda for Mr Christopher's visit. The secretary's party includes Mr Frank Wisner, undersecretary of defence for policy, who is scheduled to stay on in Beijing next week to discuss ways in which defence relations may be upgraded. Among various options being considered are expanding co-operation in peacekeeping and disaster relief operations in the Asian region, and the establishment of a Joint Commission of Defence Conversion to facilitate exchanges on converting military factories to civilian use. This will be the highest level visit by a US defence official since the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989. All this is a long way from the angry exchanges that followed Washington's decision last August to impose sanctions on the transfer of high-technology items to China in retaliation for the export of Chinese components to Pakistan for the M-11 missile. China denied that it had contravened guidelines of the Missile Technology Control Regime (MTRC). The episode marked something of a nadir in Sino-US relations. Mr Christopher will be anxious to avoid another downward spiral, but equally the US will want to see some early dividends, especially on human rights, from its policy of constructive engagement.
DOC.IN: P9199 General Government, NEC. P9721 International Affairs. P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.
DOC.TP: GOVT Government News. CMMT Comment Analysis.

DOC.TEXT: The headline on a table of European mergers and acquisitions in the Can Europe Compete series on March 7 gave a misleading impression of the merger between Reed International and Elsevier in 1992-93. DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Slovak leaders in corruption clash
DOC.TEXT: The Slovak president yesterday accused Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar of corruption in a speech marking a final break between Slovakia's two top officials and a new push to end its political paralysis. President Michal Kovac stopped short of asking for the resignation of the populist prime minister, who has led Slovakia since it gained independence in the break-up of Czechslovakia 15 months ago. But deputies later voted for Mr Meciar to face a no-confidence motion. Mr Kovac, clearly angry stunned lawmakers by claiming Mr Meciar had told him he wanted a political ally in control of privatising the economy so he could wring money out of it for his political party.
DOC.IN: P9199 General Government, NEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / EBRD business rises four-fold
DOC.TEXT: The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development last year registered about a four-fold increase in disbursements of loans and equity investments to eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. Its disbursements increased to Ecu435m (Pounds 329m) last year from Ecu122m in 1992, with signed loan and equity commitments rising to Ecu1.79bn during 1993 from Ecu946m during 1992. The bank also registered a small net profit of Ecu4m in 1993, after a loss of Ecu6m in 1992. The bank was heavily criticised last year for over-spending in administrative and refurbishment outlays. This provoked a crisis which led to the resignation of Mr Jacques Attali and his replacement by Mr Jacques de Larosiere. The bank said it had taken action to lower operating costs to Ecu137m, 8 per cent below budgeted levels.
DOC.CN: XLZ East Europe. XVZ Commonwealth of Independent States.
DOC.IN: P6081 Foreign Banking and Branches and Agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Bundesbank allows repo rate fall
DOC.TEXT: The Bundesbank yesterday sanctioned another modest decline in the repo rate, signalling that the trend towards cheaper credit in Germany was still intact. The Bundesbank allowed its key securities repurchase rate to fall to 5.94 per cent, from 5.97 per cent last week. Rates in Belgium edged lower soon after the German move, with the Belgian National Bank cutting its central rate to 6.15 per cent from 6.25 per cent. The Bundesbank's repo rate was cut to 5.97 per cent last week after the central bank had held it steady at 6 per cent since early December last year. Financial markets had been hoping for a slightly steeper cut in the repo rate, to as low as 5.90 per cent, and German stock and bond prices initially eased on the news. But money market dealers said the small rate cut had reassured the market the Bundesbank would carry on slowly reducing the cost of borrowing.
DOC.IN: P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / UK child hours under attack
DOC.TEXT: MEPs yesterday voted to prevent Britain from avoiding restrictions on the use of child labour that other European Union members have agreed to. Britain had sought four years' grace before introducing limits on working hours and mandatory rest periods for young children and adolescents aged 16 to 18. The British Labour party employment spokesman in the European Parliament, Steven Hughes, had compiled statistics showing that 39 work-related deaths in Britain since 1990 involved 16-19 year olds. He said there were indications the European Commission would support parliament's move to end the British opt-out for working children but not for adolescents. If the Commission supports the assembly's move, then the Council of Ministers can only override this by a unanimous vote.
DOC.IN: P9441 Administration of Social and Manpower Programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / MEPs reject car pollution curbs
DOC.TEXT: The European Parliament yesterday rejected proposals to tighten anti-pollution regulations against car manufacturers from 1996. MEPs threw out the proposals after strong opposition from the European Commission and the auto industry which argued it threatened jobs and investment. The vote opens the way for passage of existing proposals gradually to limit car emissions through legislation due to come into force in 1996. The car industry has been working toward a set goal of lower emissions, but became alarmed after the parliament's environment committee introduced a raft of amendments for tougher standards and a faster timetable. The amendments also demanded a 50 per cent increase in air quality standards, as well as new tax incentives for clean cars and a carbon tax to limit fuel consumption. The second reading vote at the Strasbourg parliament was eagerly awaited because it provided a test of the Maastricht treaty's new clauses on co-decision. If the amendment had secured the 260 votes necessary for passage, it would have gone back to the Council of Ministers which would have been forced to broker a compromise or face a showdown with a newly assertive parliament.
DOC.IN: P9511 Air, Water, and Solid Waste Management. P3711 Motor Vehicles and Car Bodies.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Berlusconi goes on the offensive over Fininvest
DOC.TEXT: Italian media magnate Mr Silvio Berlusconi yesterday claimed he was being subjected to an 'unprecedented campaign of political aggression', reacting to reports his Fininvest empire was being scrutinised by Milan magistrates. Mr Berlusconi accused the magistrates of permitting a rumour campaign suggesting illicit payments had been made by members of Fininvest. For the past 48 hours the Italian press has been carrying a series of leaks, clearly coming from the magistrates, suggesting arrests of at least five Fininvest officials are imminent. The reports have been linked to investigations into illicit payments allegedly made in connection with the purchase of players by Mr Berlusconi's AC Milan football club. Mr Berlusconi's attack underlined the increasingly politicised investigations of the magistrates. It also coincides with a rise in the temperature of the poll campaign, which Mr Berlusconi is hoping to win with the Forza Italia movement.
DOC.IN: P6719 Holding Companies, NEC. P9211 Courts.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Greece and Macedonia close to deal
DOC.BYLINE: By KERIN HOPE, JUDY DEMPSEY, LIONEL BARBER and REUTER
DOC.TEXT: A possible breakthrough in the dispute between Greece and Macedonia emerged last night before both sides meet under UN auspices in Geneva today. If resolved, it could help shore up a fragile stability in the southern Balkans. Mr Cyrus Vance, a former US secretary of state and UN mediator in former Yugoslavia, will discuss the draft accord with Greek foreign minister Carolos Papoulias and Mr Stevo Crvenkovski, his Macedonian counterpart. Under the proposed agreement, Macedonia would immediately alter its flag which carries a starburst symbol linked with the ancient Greek kings of Macedon. In return, Greece would drop its veto on Macedonian membership of the Conference for Security and Co-operation in Europe and participation in the European Union's aid programme for eastern Europe. Greek officials have indicated the embargo would be lifted as soon as Macedonia put another symbol on its flag and gave assurances the constitutional issue would be addressed. The possibility of movement follows this week's decision by the EU and the Commission to soft-pedal on earlier threats of legal action over Greece's trade embargo, and to acknowledge there is a 'political' element to the Macedonia dispute. In Strasbourg, Mr Papoulias said the EU's stance had given Athens room for manoeuvre. Today's talks coincide with cabinet meetings in Britain and Canada to decide how many troops, pending support from other countries, they will send to Bosnia to shore up the ceasefire. Lieutenant General Jean Marcotte, the UN's military spokesman in Zagreb, Croatia, said yesterday that any delay in sending troops 'would place the peace process in a critical situation'. Other countries, including Bangladesh, Pakistan, and particularly Turkey which has 1,000 troops on standby, have offered reinforcements. But Mr Boutros Boutros Ghali, the UN secretary-general, has ruled against sending troops from neighbouring countries. The US, which has refused to send ground forces to Bosnia until a full peace agreement is signed, was yesterday understood to be considering boosting its force in Macedonia from 300 to 700. This would allow a 400-strong Nordic force stationed in Macedonia to be sent to Bosnia. France will offer more troops on a 'roll-over' basis, sending in forces earlier to overlap with those on the ground. The Nordic countries said they were prepared to re-deploy troops from Croatia. General John Shalikashvili, chairman of the US joint chiefs of staff, said yesterday that some 50,000 western troops, half of them American, would be needed to oversee any Bosnian peace agreement, Reuter reports from Washington. He was challenging earlier reports that a smaller force of 20,000-30,000 troops, perhaps a third of them American, could monitor any final peace deal. Political notebook, Page 8
DOC.CN: MKZ Macedonia, East Europe. GRZ Greece, EC. BAZ Bosnia-Hercegovina, East Europe.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / France is in a budgetary bind, says the OECD
DOC.TEXT: The French economy will grow by 1 per cent this year, less than the 1.4 per cent forecast by the Balladur government which may thus have difficulty hitting its deficit reduction target, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development warns in a report today. The OECD says France needs to cut its interest rates further, and accepts that it wants to do this only in conjunction with Germany, and assumes that this will be possible. But it cautions that 'if German interest rates fell by less than projected, the French authorities would have to consider how to continue their policy of gradual interest rate reductions while maintaining their stable currency strategy'. It suggests that with 'no room for fiscal manoeuvre left' to boost the economy through the budget, a further easing of monetary policy would 'be the only way to support demand'. While acknowledging the pick-up in consumption in the third quarter of last year, the Paris-based organisation says the signs are 'the (economic) decline has halted, rather than that a clear-cut recovery is under way'. French government economists yesterday attributed the OECD's caution to the fact that it, like every other forecaster, failed to predict the 1992-93 recession, and to the fact that its report does not take into account the continued improvement in the last three months of 1993. This showed a 0.2 per cent rise in output, with an automatic 'carry-over' effect contributing 0.3-0.4 per cent to this year's growth. Highlighting France's budgetary bind, the OECD suggests that the government may be planning to restrain public spending too much for the short-term health of the economy, but too little to fulfil the longer-term fiscal goals set out in the Maastricht treaty for monetary union. This discrepancy arises out of the fact that the government plans to bring down its central budget deficit from FFr317bn (Pounds 36.31bn) last year to FFr300bn in 1994, but has taken few measures to contain local authorities' spending and to cut back social welfare spending. France aims to meet the Maastricht goal of bringing overall public borrowings/deficits to 3 per cent or less by 1997. But the ratio this year for France, the OECD predicts, will be nearer 5.75 per cent of gross national output in 1994, rather than the 5.1 per cent government target. The OECD criticises the tax system, despite recent reforms, as having too narrow a base, too complex a structure and too steep a progression. But the OECD endorses the government's moves to shift more of the cost of the French welfare state off the backs of companies and their employees and on to the state budget. However, it says the government may have to go further than it did in 1993 in cutting pension benefits and much further than it has in containing the cost of French healthcare. Editorial Comment, Page 21
DOC.IN: P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Paris to privatise Bull and AGF
DOC.TEXT: The French government yesterday confirmed that it plans to privatise Assurances Generales de France (AGF), the insurance group, and Groupe Bull, the troubled computer company, after the forthcoming sale of Union des Assurances de Paris (UAP), the largest French insurer. However Renault, the motor group, was omitted from the latest privatisation list, published yesterday. Its absence appeared to confirm reports that Mr Edouard Balladur, the prime minister, favoured postponing its sale until after next spring's presidential elections. Renault's omission fuelled speculation about a rift between Mr Balladur and Mr Gerard Longuet, his industry minister. Mr Longuet said in an interview in Tuesday's edition of Ouest France, a leading regional newspaper, that he hoped the group would be sold 'as quickly as possible'. However, Mr Balladur and Mr Charles Pasqua, the hardline interior minister, are believed to have advocated delay on the grounds that the privatisation could be politically sensitive at a time of rising unemployment and social instability, given Renault's status as an historic battleground for French workers' rights. The delay also reflects concern about the condition of the French stock market, which has been volatile in recent weeks. 'French equities are very jittery,' said Mr Jean-Francois Mercier, chief French economist at Salomon. 'The French must be worried about the risk of swamping the market with yet more equity.' Moreover, the success of the first phase of the privatisation drive has given Mr Balladur some flexibility over the timing of future issues. His government originally budgeted to raise FFr55bn (Pounds 6.3bn) from its 1994 share issues. It has already yielded FFr33bn from last month's sale of the Elf-Aquitaine oil group, with another FFr28bn expected from the UAP issue. This means that the government will beat this year's financial target even before selling its AGF stake, which should be worth FFr15bn. Mr Edmond Alphandery, economy minister, yesterday said the proceeds of the AGF issue were needed to recapitalise a number of state-controlled companies. The value of the Bull privatisation is more difficult to assess given that it is likely to be phased into several stages, including a small public offer and the sale of minority stakes to industrial partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Economic Watch: Oil demand revised upwards
DOC.TEXT: The International Energy Agency forecast for oil demand in OECD countries in the first quarter of 1994 has been revised upwards by 0.1m barrels a day, to 40.3m. European demand is expected to be temporarily subdued as a result of very mild weather, but is projected to rise modestly in 1994, to 13.7m b/d, from 13.6m in 1993. The IEA revised upwards European demand in the fourth quarter of 1993 by 0.2m b/d to 14m b/d, but the agency said this reflected an increase in stocks, rather than any underlying increase in oil consumption. Further stockbuilding in Europe during January has left stock levels 'above normal', the IEA said. Outside the OECD, demand in the former Soviet Union is expected to decline by 0.6m bpd in 1994, from 5.6m bpd in 1993. The Hamburg-based HWWA economic research institute has forecast real growth of 5 per cent in German exports in 1994, after a 6 per cent fall in 1993. East German exports should also grow, it said. Western German retail trading sales fell a real 2 per cent in January from a year earlier, and stagnated in nominal terms. Retail sales in January were down an average 37 per cent from December. Hungary's unemployment rate fell to 12.6 per cent in February from 12.8 per cent in January, with the number of registered unemployed falling by 11,000, to 630,600.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Voting row goes to heart of EU's fault lines: How a dispute among the 12 has put the prospects for the 16 in jeopardy
DOC.TEXT: Britain and Spain will come under intense pressure from their European partners to settle the EU power-sharing dispute which threatens to prevent four new members - Sweden, Finland, Austria and Norway - entering the Union. Britain in particular, has been identified as the villain in sabotaging prospects for the wider Europe it says it wants. Mr Klaus Kinkel, Germany's foreign minister, mainly blamed the UK when the enlargement negotiations broke up in rancour late Tuesday night, to resume in Brussels next Tuesday. London and Madrid, with lukewarm support from the Italians, insist on keeping the weighted voting rules of the 12 - where two large and one small countries combining 23 out of 76 votes can block measures - for a Union of 16. Their nine partners want to move the threshold to 27 out of 90 votes, keeping the same, roughly 30 per cent proportion for the 'blocking minority', after the four newcomers arrive. 'The Nine won't blink on the 27 votes,' Mr Piet Dankert, the Dutch minister for Europe warned early yesterday. British officials maintain that only the Benelux countries and possibly France firmly oppose the UK and Spain, with a large pool in between for both sides to fish in before next Tuesday. The known evidence from what has nevertheless been a row behind closed doors suggests they are wrong. First, the power-sharing issue goes to the heart of the divisions in the Union which the Maastricht treaty failed to close: between North and South, between big and small member states, between the sovereignty-conscious who prefer inter-governmental co-operation, and federalists who want to tighten European integration and make decisions at EU level easier. But more immediately, countries like Germany and Holland - both with greater right to complain about under-representation in the Council than the UK or Spain - feel certain that the European Parliament will not ratify the accession treaty if EU law-making is made more difficult by a shrinking minority. Parliament formally has to decide whether to go ahead today. This might be stretched to next week. Much beyond that, however, and the January 1995 enlargement target could be lost, along with momentum in the applicant countries which still have to convince their voters to endorse entry. Although nobody disputes that the UK and Spain can block the decision, there is a growing feeling in Brussels that Britain has misread the situation - unless it is putting down markers now for the 1996 constitutional review to which the 12 heads of government (including Mr Major and Mr Felipe Gonzalez) in June 1992 remitted the votes issue. Mr Jacques Delors, Commission president, has suggested moving to 27 votes for the moment, and for the 12 leaders to set up a committee to study vote distribution ahead of 1996, specifically taking into account British, Spanish, Italian, and also German concerns. This looks like the only sort of framework which can resolve the dispute and deliver a Europe of 16 next year - and the British and Spanish governments can expect to be told so in no uncertain terms in the few days left.
DOC.CN: QRZ European Economic Community (EC). SEZ Sweden, West Europe. ATZ Austria, West Europe. NOZ Norway, West Europe. FIZ Finland, West Europe. GBZ United Kingdom, EC. ESZ Spain, EC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Norway unflustered by collapse of talks
DOC.TEXT: Norway yesterday appeared unflustered by the hiatus in its fraught negotiations on terms for entry to the European Union as the government presented the wrangles within the EU on the talks as evidence that it was driving a good deal for Oslo, writes Hugh Carnegy in Stockholm. Mr Jan Henry Olsen, the Norwegian fisheries minister - given a virtual veto on the country's entry terms by Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland - said he would recommend acceptance of a proposed deal blocked only by Spain when the talks stalled in Brussels. 'If Spain accepts the proposed solution on fish already accepted by the 11 other EU members and Norway, I will say yes to membership and recommend others to do the same,' said Mr Olsen formerly a staunch opponent of Norwegian entry to the union. In Stockholm, Mr Carl Bildt, Swedish prime minister, said he was not concerned by the delay in Brussels. 'This is not a breakdown in negotiations, but a one week delay. There is no reason to believe Sweden's entry will be delayed,' he said.
DOC.CN: NOZ Norway, West Europe. SEZ Sweden, West Europe. ESZ Spain, EC.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs. P091 Commercial Fishing.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Brussels to probe aid for airlines
DOC.TEXT: The European Commission is to investigate the state aid which Portugal and Greecehave offered to their national airlines, TAP-Air Portugal and Olympic Airways. The investigation is likely to fuel the long-running row between member states over the Commission's efforts to curtail state aid to airlines - a dispute that seems likely to gather pace with the announcement of a new state package for Air France in Paris this week. The Commission's investigation into TAP follows the Portuguese government's approval two months ago of a Es180bn (Pounds 687m) aid package for the airline, designed to bail out the loss-making group as part of a broader restructuring programme. This aid, which would absorb TAP's Es124,4 debts, will be allocated in four tranches over the next four years, according to the plans submitted to the Commission by the Portuguese government. At the same time the Commission will examine the Ecu2bn (Pounds 1.51bn) of state aid that the Greek government has offered to Olympic Airways. This aid is to be split into two parts, with Ecu1.1bn designated to absorb Olympic's previous debts and Ecu96m earmarked for future capital projects. Commission officials said yesterday the investigations into state aid for airlines were now almost standard policy, given the increasingly tough line that the Commission has taken in recent years towards state subsidies in European industry. Last December the Commission approved IPounds 175m (Pounds 168m) aid for Irish carrier Aer Lingus after a similar investigation, although it insisted the aid could only be used to restore the company to financial viability and could not be used to distort the market. A more controversial investigation into the FFr1.5bn (Pounds 174m) of aid for Air France is under way, with results expected in several months. The question at stake will be whether the Greek and Portuguese aid represents a 'one-off' attempt to make the airlines viable for future competition, Commission officials said. Although they insisted that 'one-off' aid was still permissible, under Commission rules, aid that could seriously distort the market would not be permitted.
DOC.CO: Transportes Aereos Portugueses. Olympic Airways. Air France.
DOC.CN: GRZ Greece, EC. PTZ Portugal, EC. FRZ France, EC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Catalonia sees war of words as dangerous fantasy: A look at the growing row over the Catalan language law which has been referred to Spain's highest court
DOC.TEXT: In Scoop, the British writer Evelyn Waugh's seminal satire on journalistic jaunts, a celebrated war correspondent sent to cover a revolution in a Balkans capital oversleeps in his train carriage, wakes up in the wrong city, blithely rattles off dispatches about flaming churches and dead children, and succeeds in creating financial panic, famine and a revolution on his hotel doorstep. Waugh's fable resurfaced two weeks ago in an editorial on the Catalan language question in the Barcelona newspaper La Vanguardia. Mr Jordi Pujol, president of Catalonia's autonomous government, the Generalitat, since 1980, has since seized the story to explain in subsequent press conferences that the supposed row is a fantasy which could turn dangerous. At issue is a Catalan language law, unanimously passed by Catalonia's parliament 11 years ago in one of Mr Pujol's earliest legislative initiatives, that has been referred by the Supreme Court in Madrid to the Constitutional Court, an even higher Madrid-based judicial body whose 12 members are the watchdogs of civic rights and duties. The Constitutional Court has to decide whether the language law infringes the rights of Spanish speakers in Catalonia by forcing them to learn Catalan, a language that the post-Franco constitution asserts is co-official with Spanish in the area. It is expected to spend months pondering over its ruling. In Mr Pujol's view there is no issue and no row - only interested parties who seek to rock Catalonia's calm. The Scoop-like correspondent creating the storm is a well-known extreme right-winger in Barcelona and a lawyer, Mr Esteban Gomez Rovira, aided and abetted by the conservative Madrid newspaper ABC. Mr Gomez Rovira has been fighting legal battles to curb the growing use of Catalan in the area's schools ever since the language law was enacted. In 1985 and 1987 he survived bomb attacks from Catalan extremists. His latest assault, now before the Constitutional Court, follows what he terms 'a turn of the screw by the Generalitat'. The twist by Mr Pujol's government, which has so far gained the backing of the judiciary for its educational initiatives, has been its insistence on Catalan-only schooling for children up to the age of seven under a new policy called 'linguistic immersion'. Mr Gomez Rovira sees the development as one step further in the creation of a monolingual culture that will destroy 'the unity of Spain'. ABC has given the lawyer a platform for his views ('it has made all the difference', he says). The newspaper claims that Mr Pujol is seeking to stamp out Spanish just as Francoism sought to eradicate the language of Catalonia. Surveys conducted by the Generalitat, and a succession of views in Barcelona from a cross-section of native Catalans and of immigrants to the area, suggest a very different picture to the one painted by ABC. The vast majority are functionally bilingual; they do not question the Generalitat's weighting towards Catalan and they are not 'unlearning' their Spanish. Unlike other minority languages that have become nationalist emblems, Catalan is a romance language that is easy to learn and, more importantly, it is very much a living language that carries social prestige. Immigrants from southern Spain, who swelled Barcelona dormitory towns such as Santa Coloma from 12,000 in the 1950s to 140,000 today, wanted to learn the language of the foreman on the building site and in the workshop. Mr Pujol's education department claims that over the past five years the percentage of Catalonia's 6m inhabitants that does not understand Catalan has been reduced from 9.4 per cent to 6.2 per cent; nearly 94 per cent understand Catalan, 68 per cent can speak and read it and 40 per cent can write it. The department's officials say that far from discriminating against immigrants, the 'linguistic immersion' policy wants to ensure that children from Spanish-speaking homes will have an equal opportunity in a schooling system where more than half the subjects are taught in Catalan. To date, less than 500 parents have backed Mr Gomez Rovira's campaign to demand Spanish-language schooling with Catalan as an optional subject. Mr Pujol believes that the cornerstone of continued calm and consensus in Catalonia is the maintenance of the present impulse towards cementing a bilingual society. He fears that the Constitutional Court might, like Mr Gomez Rovira and the Scoop journalist, wake up at the wrong station, and create an artificial conflict by upholding a dual schooling system that would prove dangerously divisive.
DOC.IN: P9211 Courts.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / A tale of paper cod and accelerated cohesion fish: The Greek handling of the talks unravelled the EU's Byzantine solution to the fishing row
DOC.TEXT: A dispute over the conduct of the talks, rather than the content of the negotiations, appears to have stood in the way of the European Union clinching entry terms with Norway late on Tuesday night, when ministerial negotiations in Brussels on EU enlargement broke up in disarray Mr Javier Solana, the Spanish foreign minister, walked out of the negotiations for some two hours, irritated by the way the Greek presidency of the EU presented Spain with what he evidently saw as a 'take it or leave it' offer on access to Norwegian fish, without allowing time for the Spanish to examine the details. Spanish officials at the meeting nevertheless confirmed that they were prepared to give serious consideration to the content of the offer. The main obstacle to concluding terms with Norway is Spanish insistence that it get back the 7,000 tonnes of cod its fishing fleet used to catch in Norwegian waters before it was barred in 1981. Madrid equally wants the cod Norway ceded to the EU as part of this year's European Economic Area (EEA) free trade zone treaty 'consolidated' as part of a permanent quota. This amounts to 7,250 tonnes this year, rising to 11,000 tonnes in 1997, with the so-called 'cohesion' or poor countries, Spain and Portugal, getting 45 per cent each, and Greece and Ireland splitting the rest. But for over a year Oslo has unflinchingly refused to give up a single extra fish. 'I will stand tall and firm and say No,' Mr Jan Henry Olsen, Norway's fisheries minister, said on Tuesday, as Spain reiterated its threat to veto Norwegian entry unless he budged. The European Commission's alchemists, however, were busy working up a seemingly impossible formula to save the face of both Madrid and Oslo. Its main elements are: To bring forward the 11,000 tonnes quota for 1997 to this year (these are known as 'accelerated cohesion fish'). Under the EEA, the Union also gets 2.9 per cent of the total Norwegian waters cod quota, or about 40,000 tonnes this year. But the cod stock is rising because of careful Norwegian fisheries management, promising a higher tonnage for the EU in coming years. Brussels wants to satisfy Spain's demands by giving it these additional tonnes (known as 'paper fish', because at the moment they are only there on paper). Anticipating that Spain will not be satisfied, the Commission has also looked at 'other people's fish'. Brussels suggests the Union buys a portion of Russia's cod quota in Norwegian waters, allocate it to Spain, and pass the bill through Oslo's contribution to the EU budget. Norwegian officials, with whom this formula had to be worked out, were obviously familiar with the details of this package; Spanish officials, equally obviously, were not. When Mr Theodoros Pangalos, the Greek European affairs minister chairing the EU Council of Ministers, presented Spain with what it regarded as a fait accompli, Mr Solana took it as an affront and left for his embassy. Spanish officials say they need time to study the implications, but concede that the Commission formula could turn dross, or at least cod, into gold.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 10 MAR 94 / Barclays considers default provisions to limit profit swings
DOC.TEXT: Barclays, the largest UK bank, is working on plans to even out cyclical swings in its profits by making a small provision for default each time it lends money. It hopes this will prevent large rises in loan provisions during recessions. Mr Martin Taylor, Barclays' new chief executive, is backing the initiative although it was discussed before he took up his post full-time in January. Barclays announces its 1993 profits today, after a Pounds 242m loss in 1992. Banks suffered from an unprecedented swing in their profits in the five years from 1987 because they boosted earnings by increasing loans rapidly in the late 1980s. They were then hit by a wave of bad debt provisions in the recession. Banks carry general provisions against losses they expect from loans which appear to be sound, but Barclays wants to make this more exact. It would book a small loss against each loan, set according to the chance of it not being repaid. The bank is trying to analyse the risks over full economic cycles of particular types of lending, such as small corporate loans or those to particular industries. Mr Taylor is thought to be keen to implement the new approach next year. Barclays' directors believe that by making loans carry a small provision based on risk, they could discourage branch managers both from lending too much during economic booms and refusing loans during recession. However, the initiative could be hard to implement because of the difficulty of assessing risk accurately. The move could also be opposed by bank auditors, who might regard it as an attempt to smooth profits by mis-stating earnings. The bank could also increase its tax liability by making general provisions. Specific provisions against loans clearly in danger of default are tax deductible, but general provisions against expected loss are not. Barclays signalled a move towards evening out volatility in profits when it increased its general provisions by Pounds 118m in the first half of 1993. It holds general provisions worth about 0.6 per cent of its loans and advances. Mr Taylor is thought to be keen to implement the idea in full. If Barclays cannot gain approval from auditors, it might bring in the change internally in separate management accounts. Mr Taylor is thought to be keen to implement the idea in full. If Barclays cannot gain approval from auditors, it might bring in the change internally in separate management accounts. Mr Taylor was chosen as chief executive last autumn after the bank faced strong criticism for its performance.
