DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Banks may be held liable for pollution clean-ups
DOC.TEXT: Banks could be held liable for cleaning up pollution caused by companies to which they have made loans, under government proposals published yesterday. The consultation paper from the Department of the Environment and the Welsh Office suggests that a fund of millions of pounds might also be needed to cover pollution costs where no person or organisation could be held liable. But it stresses that the UK wants to avoid the problems faced by the US's Superfund, which has seen clean-up costs outstripping its budget. The report tackles questions about who should pay to clean up contaminated land, and how clean it should be. It recommends that land needs to be cleaned only to the extent of being 'suitable for use', not to its original state of cleanliness. Ms Clare Deanesly of Gouldens, the solicitors, said yesterday: 'The question that is really up in the air is liability for pollution that occurred in the past. There has been a lot of buck-passing between the public and private sectors.' The legal problems were highlighted in December in a court battle between Eastern Counties Leather and Cambridge Water over liability for water pollution. Last year the government scrapped plans for a register of contaminated land, part of the 1990 Environmental Protection Act, because of fears that it would cause property blight and would place too great a financial burden on local authorities. Ministers are concerned that the legal uncertainties are preventing companies from securing loans and insurance, and making it preferable to develop greenfield sites rather than old industrial blackspots. The new proposals were attacked last night by banks, property companies and environmentalists. Ms Hilary Thompson, head of the environmental unit at National Westminster Bank, called for details of the banks' possible exposure to be clarified. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said: 'Our disappointment is that, after a year-long review, the government's recommendations remain so tentative.' Responses to the paper are due by May 3.
DOC.IN: P6021 National Commercial Banks. P9511 Air, Water, and Solid Waste Management.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Government split over control of education
DOC.TEXT: A split between the prime minister's office and the Department of Education opened yesterday over future local government control of education. Mr Graham Bright, parliamentary private secretary to Mr John Major, appeared to tell his local county council in a letter that local government re-organisation in England would mean the abolition of local education authorities. He said: 'I very much hope that Bedfordshire County Council will recognise that the introduction of grant-maintained status for schools is permanent and that its own imminent demise signals the end for local education authorities.' But the education department said that it had no plans to abolish local education authorities 'in the lifetime of this parliament'. Local government re-organisation is due to take place in 1995 and 1996, before the next general election is due. Education ministers have, however, strongly encouraged schools to opt out of local authority control, and instead take their funding directly from Whitehall. Labour seized on Mr Bright's comments as an admission of a Tory 'hidden agenda'. Education is a county responsibility in non-metropolitan England, and counties are due to be split into smaller all-purpose authorities under the government's guidance to the Local Government Commission. It had been assumed that the new unitary councils would inherit responsibility for education, the largest single item of local government spending. County education officers oppose re-organisation, saying that it would weaken services. Mr Bright attacked 'the re-creation of the old local authority empire over schools', saying this would favour 'the most hidebound vested interests in education'. Bedfordshire, which has no overall political control, said that 13 of the county's schools had opted out, while 277 remained in county control. It added that Mr Bright appeared to have prejudged the outcome of the review, which could still, under government guidelines, recommend that the two-tier system continue. Mrs Ann Taylor, shadow education secretary, said the comments were 'a mixture of admission of the government's hidden agenda, and a sign of desperation that the grant-maintained schools are not catching on in anything like the way the government intended'. She added that the practical problems of abolishing local education authorities would be too great, as the government would not be able to run schools in the country.
DOC.IN: P9411 Administration of Educational Programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Prisoners involved in benefits fraud to be traced
DOC.TEXT: Steps are being taken to trace prisoners involved in an alleged multi-million pound benefits fraud. A report on BBC's Here and Now programme says up to 4,000 prisoners are claiming benefits - at an annual cost of Pounds 9m to Pounds 25m. The Department of Social Security said it believed the programme exaggerates the fraud but confirmed that the Prison Service gave the DSS details of all 35,000 convicted inmates in prison last week.
DOC.IN: P9441 Administration of Social and Manpower Programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Labour attacks cuts in criminal injury awards
DOC.TEXT: The government was forced on to the defensive yesterday by Labour attacks on plans to speed up the criminal injuries compensation scheme. Mr John Major defended the government's plans to replace individual assesments with a tariff scheme during irritable question time exchanges. The prime minister said the changes, which will take effect in April, would make the system more efficient and speed up payments to claimants. But it later emerged that the changes would reduce the annual bill for compensation payments from about Pounds 500m a year to Pounds 250m by the end of the decade. The government expects 46 per cent of claimants to be worse off under the new system, which will replace individual assessment with fixed payments. The proposals have been criticised in both houses of parliament, and there is growing unrest among Conservative backbenchers about the impact on the victims of crime. Mr John Smith, Labour leader, sought to exploit Tory unease by claiming that compensation for police officers seriously injured in criminal attacks would fall from Pounds 121,000 to Pounds 7,500. He said that a young woman with two children who saw her husband murdered at her own front door had received Pounds 137,000 under the existing scheme, but would have received only Pounds 17,000 after April. 'Why should she lose Pounds 120,000 under a government cost-cutting exercise?' he asked. 'Is it not bad enough that crime has doubled under this government without making the victims pay for it?'
DOC.IN: P922 Public Order and Safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Fourth mobile phone network to be launched
DOC.TEXT: Hutchison Microtel yesterday confirmed that it would be launching a cellular mobile network next month and announced that it would be called 'Orange'. The network will be the UK's fourth, competing against Vodafone, Cellnet and Mercury One-2-One, which was launched within the M25 area last September. Microtel chose the name in an effort to conjure up the image of cellular communications as 'fresh, attractive, and not impossibly complicated to use'. Microtel, whose largest shareholder is Hutchison Whampoa, the Hong Kong conglomerate, refused to disclose the Orange tariffs yesterday, but said they would be 'highly competitive' with those of existing networks. The launch of One-2-One last year, with free local calls on weekday evenings and at weekends, is widely credited with ensuring the breakthrough of cellular mobile telephony into the consumer market. The Orange network is based on the same technology as One-2-One, but it will be more extensive at launch. It will cover more than half of the UK's population initially, extending to 90 per cent by mid-1995. One-2-One's network is limited to south-east England, although it is being ex-panded. The Orange network will be digital, as is One-2-One. The handsets are likely to be more expensive than those for the analogue networks run by Vodafone and Cellnet, but Orange is likely to compensate with cheaper operating charges. There has been much speculation that Hutchison Whampoa has tried to sell Microtel, in which it has invested more than Pounds 700m. Last year the conglomerate announced its intention to reduce its telecommunications operations outside Hong Kong, and closed its unsuccessful Rabbit telepoint venture in the UK. Lex, Page 20

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Criminal injury changes attacked
DOC.TEXT: The government was forced on to the defensive yesterday by Labour attacks on plans to speed up the criminal injuries compensation scheme, Kevin Brown writes. Mr John Major defended the government's plans to replace individual assessments with a tariff scheme during question-time exchanges. The prime minister said the changes, which will take effect in April, would make the system more efficient and speed up payments to claimants. But it later emerged that the changes would reduce the annual bill for compensation payments from about Pounds 500m a year to Pounds 250m by the year 2000. DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Canal paths used for fibre-optic grid
DOC.TEXT: Competition for long-distance telecommunications traffic was stepped up yesterday by the launch of a company using Britain's canal tow-paths to build a fibre-optic network. Fibreway says it is the first company engaged solely in the wholesaling of capacity to other operators. It will offer no services directly to end-users, but will sell capacity to the growing array of entrants to the UK market. Construction of a link between Edinburgh and Glasgow is under way, with others planned in the Midlands. With more than 2,000 miles of canal available, the potential exists to create a network linking most of the UK's biggest cities. The three existing long-distance networks are owned by companies which also provide telecoms services to consumers. They are British Telecommunications, Mercury, and Energis, which will launch a service next month. Fibreway's largest shareholder is GPT, the telecoms equipment joint venture between GEC and Siemens, the German group. It is acting in partnership with British Waterways. Mr Gerry Boothroyd, Fibreway's director, said that initial investment would be in the 'tens of millions', with network construction determined by demand. Cable companies building local networks in urban areas are keen to see a diversity of long-distance operators. Mr Eugene Connell, head of UK operations for Nynex, the US group making significant UK cable investments, expressed 'serious interest' in the new operator as a means of linking Nynex's franchises in different parts of the country. The idea of using canal tow-paths for a telecoms network has been in the air for several years, but appeared to founder two years ago when Sprint, the US long-distance carrier, dropped plans to build its own UK network. The railways are already used for telecoms. Part of Mercury's long-distance network runs alongside the tracks, and British Rail's own telecoms subsidiary is preparing to offer a service to outside operators.
DOC.IN: P1623 Water, Sewer and Utility Lines.
DOC.TP: TECH Services Services use. RES Facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Fowler plays Euro defence card
DOC.TEXT: The Conservative party is putting defence firmly at the heart of its campaign for the European elections in June. Sir Norman Fowler, the party chairman, and Mr Malcolm Rifkind, the defence secretary, yesterday launched a sweeping attack bracketing both main opposition parties together for the purposes of the assault. With a strong Liberal Democrat challenge expected in Tory seats in the south-west of England - a region in which the defence industry is one of the largest employers - many of yesterday's most vituperative comments were aimed at Mr Paddy Ashdown's party. The two Tory politicians also used a Westminster press conference to launch a 25-page document setting out the principal differences on defence between all three leading parties. The main thrust of Sir Norman's attack was to try to tar Labour and the Liberal Democrats with the same brush by claiming that there was a latter-day 'Lib-Lab pact' on defence. This consisted of a three-part plan comprising 'drastic' defence cuts, the surrender of control over Britain's security policy to Brussels and the creation of a European army. 'On defence Labour and the Liberals have the same agenda,' he said. Mr Rifkind attacked the 'brave captain Ashdown' who liked to wrap himself in the union flag and present himself as a great warrior but had appeared on CND platforms 'not all that long ago'. In a development which may disconcert Tory backbenchers who have complained that recent defence cuts were Treasury-driven, there was a strong emphasis on good housekeeping in yesterday's document. 'It remains incumbent upon the Ministry of Defence to deliver the nation's required war fighting capability at least cost to the taxpayer,' the document says. One of the chief justifications for Nato remaining the cornerstone of Britain's defence policy is that otherwise 'we would have to spend more to achieve the level of security we have now'. Mr David Clark, shadow defence secretary, described the press conference as 'a panic reaction by a government that has grossly mismanaged Britain's defences'. Defending Britain's Interests. Conservative Political Centre Bookshop, 32 Smith Square, London SW1P 3HH. Pounds 3.
DOC.IN: P9199 General Government, NEC. P9711 National Security.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Spate of TV mergers attacked
DOC.TEXT: The Independent Television Commission's chief executive last night attacked the recent spate of takeovers in ITV and suggested that they were driven more by ambition than commercial considerations. Mr David Glencross said in a hard-hitting speech to the Royal Television Society that the advantages of size were not as clear-cut as often claimed. He was speaking as MAI's bid for Anglia Television went unconditional and after Carlton Communications's takeover of Central and Granada's successful hostile bid for London Weekend Television. Some time and expense would be saved by simplifying decision-taking in ITV but, he said, takeovers were driven by three factors. 'In order of priority they are ambition, ambition and ambition.' He added that already nearly Pounds 50m had been spent in servicing the deals. Even the newly enlarged ITV companies were small by international standards and it was a misconception to think size by itself would create a thriving programme export business. Mr Glencross said: 'There is nothing to stop a consortium of the ITV companies, and the BBC too, if it wishes, getting together to produce for the export market without any change in the ownership rules.' The government decision to allow larger ITV companies to be taken over by each other had 'added to, rather than resolved the uncertainty about the future of ITV'. Smaller companies could be left dangerously exposed. Mr Glencross criticised the 1990 Broadcasting Act for making the ITV companies the most taxed television companies in the world. Last year Pounds 360m, a quarter of ITV's advertising and sponsorship revenue, went to the Treasury, almost as much as the total revenue of Channel 4. He added: 'So in effect the cost of an entire national television channel is being handed to the Treasury in addition to the normal corporation tax paid by the Channel 3 companies.' The ITC chief executive also said that: Newspaper stakes in ITV should be able to rise from 20 per cent to 30 per cent but that limit should be applied by stages to satellite groups such as British Sky Broadcasting, half-owned by Mr Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. A new Channel 5 could start within two years without inhibiting the launch of digital services.
DOC.IN: P4833 Television Broadcasting Stations. P2711 Newspapers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / From sop to soap-opera success: The S4C channel's rise to Oscar contender
DOC.TEXT: In its early days so few people watched S4C, the Welsh fourth channel, the joke was that it would have been been cheaper to give Welsh speakers free video recorders. More than a decade later all that has changed. The television channel that was seen as a political sop to the Welsh nationalists has not only found an audience and helped to stimulate a television and film production industry, but even has a seat at the Oscars ceremony in Los Angeles later this month. The Welsh-language film Hedd Wyn, the story of a poet from Trawsfynydd and his death in the trenches during the first world war, is one of five nominations for the foreign film Oscar. S4C commissioned and paid for the Pounds 700,000 film, which has already won a Royal Television Society award for best UK drama. 'I'm keeping my fingers crossed that I may go out with an Oscar,' says Mr Geraint Stanley Jones, who retires at the end of next month after five years running the channel. 'What it means is that finally there's a recognition that small could be quite good actually and that a funny language may not be that restrictive,' says the S4C chief executive who was formerly the BBC's first managing director of regional programmes. Recently S4C has migrated from Wales to BBC 2 with its Welsh language soap opera Pobol Y Cwm - People of the Valleys. The popular drama, complete with English sub-titles, has been getting afternoon audiences of about 600,000. With the original S4C viewing attracting audiences of about 250,000, 1m viewers for Pobol Y Cwm might be possible in future. The channel broadcasts 32 hours a week in Welsh, although a growing percentage of Welsh-language programmes carry English sub-titles. The rest of the time S4C reschedules popular Channel 4 programmes such as Brookside and The Big Breakfast. Placing more emphasis on drama and English sub-titles has resulted in increased ratings. In November 1988 the top 10 Welsh-language programmes averaged 74,700 viewers each. By November 1992 this figure had risen to 125,600 and by last November to 202,700. S4C is now funded by a 3.2 per cent share of non-satellite advertising revenue - which includes income from the breakfast franchise and Channel 4 - paid in the form of a block grant from the Treasury via the Department of National Heritage. Last year this accounted for Pounds 55.7m. The channel is also free to sell its own advertising and is expected to raise Pounds 6m this year. It also expects Pounds 10m in co-production money - S4C has made programmes with broadcasters as diverse as ZDF of Germany, ABC of Australia and Fujisanki of Japan, with a particular emphasis on animation. The animated tales of Shakespeare sold to 50 countries and the station is working on a multi-million pound animation of the Old Testament with Christmas Films of Moscow. As Mr Stanley Jones hands over to the new chief executive Mr Huw Jones, a leading Welsh independent producer, it seems a very reasonable legacy for a channel born after Mr Gwynfor Evans, president of Plaid Cymru, the Welsh nationalist party, threatened to go on hunger strike if one was not created.
DOC.IN: P4833 Television Broadcasting Stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / ITC urged to prevent advert sale monopoly
DOC.TEXT: Two leading organisations representing the advertising industry have called for strict regulation of television advertising sales to prevent what are in effect monopolies developing, Raymond Snoddy writes. The Institute of Practitioners in Advertising and the Association of Media Independents have told the Independent Television Commission they would accept one sales point being responsible for up to 25 per cent of all television advertising in the UK - but only with conditions. The ITC is looking at its rules governing the sale of television advertising with the presumption that the maximum threshold will be lifted from 25 per cent of ITV to 25 per cent of all television sales. If that happens the IPA wants to see a prohibition on advertising being sold in a package for two or more competing television services such as regional ITV companies, GMTV, the breakfast service, Channel 4 or the two London ITV stations. The institute also wants to see a ban on any advertising sales points with 25 per cent of the market having shareholdings in, or influence over, a competitor. The media independents want a sales structure 'which is independent, accountable and transparent'. The institute wants any sales organisation with more than 20 per cent of the market to be a separate legal entity with independent directors, and to declare net quarterly revenue to clear criteria.
DOC.IN: P7313 Radio, Television, Publisher Representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Lib Dems target urban Tory seats
DOC.TEXT: The Liberal Democrats yesterday outlined plans to target urban Conservative seats in an attempt to establish the party as the main metropolitan alternative to Labour in the May local government elections. Launching a paper on urban policy Mr Paddy Ashdown, the Liberal Democrat leader, said Britain's rundown cities could be regenerated through decentralisation and wider council powers over taxation and planning. The paper, Reclaiming the City, aims to build on the Liberal Democrat's successes in last year's county council elections, when the party made widespread gains at the expense of the Tories. It attacks the government for imposing undemocratic quangos on local government and 'failing either to arrest the underlying processes of urban decay or to ameliorate the effects'. Mr Ashdown said the paper was intended to challenge the public view of the Liberal Democrats as a rural party of the south-west of England, Scotland and Wales. 'Up and down the country we are moving away from being a party exclusively winning seats in rural areas and one which is becoming an inner-city alternative to the Labour party,' he said. The paper is based on the Liberal Democrats' long-standing commitment to decentralise local government under a new tier of regional assemblies for Scotland, Wales and the English regions. It calls for lower business rates; local agencies to mobilise savings and channel national and European funds into development projects; tax relief for municipal development bonds; and workforce agreements to ensure that local people benefit directly from jobs created by redevelopment projects. It also urges the use of planning law to direct businesses and homes back to inner-city areas, combined with a development tax to discourage development on greenfield sites. The paper also calls for a substantial increase in light rail and other public transport systems.
DOC.IN: P8651 Political Organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Economic indicator's rise ends
DOC.TEXT: The recent rise in the Central Statistical Office's longer leading index has ended, new data showed yesterday. The index is designed to detect turning points in the economy about a year in advance. The index, whose components include the yield curve, building starts, the financial balances of industrial and commercial companies and business optimism, is now flat. This is mainly due to a large downward revision to December's housebuilding figures. However, the shorter leading index - intended to highlight changes in activity about five months ahead using share prices, car registrations and the Gallup index of consumer confidence - continued its 15-month rise. The coincident indicator, which tracks the business cycle, has risen steadily from its trough in the second quarter of 1992. All its components - including GDP at factor cost, industrial production, retail sales and M0 money supply - have contributed this year.
DOC.IN: P9311 Finance, Taxation, and Monetary Policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Scottish exports up 30% in 1993
DOC.TEXT: Exports of manufactured goods from Scotland rose by more than 30 per cent in value last year, says a new index of Scottish exports, James Buxton writes. The index, based on figures from 26 companies which account for 60 per cent of all Scottish exports, rose from its base of 100 in the first quarter to 130.1 for the fourth quarter, suggesting exports worth Pounds 10.9bn in the whole of 1993. Although all industrial sectors showed growth, the strongest export sector was computers. The index is compiled by Scottish Council Development and Industry, which lobbies for economic development.
DOC.IN: P9611 Administration of General Economic Programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Oftel imposes tighter regime on BT charges
DOC.TEXT: British Telecommunications faces a sharp increase in regulation as Oftel, the telecommunications watchdog, tries to open the UK market to greater competition. A new supervisory regime announced yesterday by Oftel will provide for the regulator to set and publish the price of more than 70 charges levied by BT on competitors needing to use its network to carry their calls. It will also force BT to publish separate accounts for its network and retail businesses to reduce the advantage the company gains as a retailer from owning the country's largest telecoms network. Payments to BT, which controls about 90 per cent of the UK telecoms market, represent about half of the total costs of rival operators. The largest rival is Mercury, but dozens of new operators have gained licences in the past two years, including cable companies build-ing combined television and telephone networks in urban areas. Mr Don Cruickshank, Oftel director-general, said the changes were essential to promote a transparent, competitive telecoms market. He said: 'I hope BT will increasingly see other operators as customers as well as competitors.' BT views new operators solely as a threat, however, and is anxious to avoid becoming little more than a wholesaler of network capacity to other service providers. At present it sets charges for competitors using its network by negotiation, with a right of appeal to Oftel - exercised twice by Mercury. The prices have been confidential and vary between operators. In future, competitors will pay for key interconnection services at standard, published tariffs set by Oftel. BT condemned Oftel's 'costly increase in regulation'. But Mr Michael Hepher, BT managing director, has assured Oftel of co-operation in the introduction of accounting separation, which will apply from this financial year. Mr Cruickshank said the level of detailed regulation proposed was 'absolutely essential' to develop competition. He added: 'BT is presently not offering the same price for the same thing to competitors and it is not demonstrating to operators how prices are reached.' Oftel's standard interconnection charges will initially be based on its determination last year of the long-running dispute between BT and Mercury over network payments. Mercury is contesting the determination in the High Court in an attempt to secure a more favourable settlement. Mr Cruickshank made no further concessions to Mercury yesterday but repeated his intention to examine its proposals as a medium-term option. Mr Richard Woollam, director-general of the Cable Television Association, said Oftel's plans were 'roughly in line with what we have been looking for'.
DOC.IN: P4812 Radiotelephone Communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Malaysia still cool after Prior visit
DOC.TEXT: Senior Malaysian officials have warned that it may take some time for Britain to improve relations. This is in spite of attempts by leading British business figures to persuade Kuala Lumpur to lift an order banning UK companies from participating in new government contracts. Dr Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysia's prime minister, yesterday had a lengthy meeting with Lord Prior, chairman of GEC and a former British cabinet minister. Although British diplomats in Kuala Lumpur stressed that Lord Prior's secretive two-day visit to Malaysia was private, a senior official in London said the mission 'had the blessing of Downing Street'. Lord Prior was believed to be on his way back to London last night and is expected to report to Mr John Major today on his meeting with Dr Mahathir. Sir Charles Powell, a director of Trafalgar House and former foreign affairs adviser to Mr Major and Baroness Thatcher, has also been in Malaysia. GEC is among the British companies hardest hit by the Malaysian ban. Together with Trafalgar House and Balfour Beatty, it is part of an Anglo-Japanese consortium which had been hoping to carry out a large part of the work on a new Pounds 3bn international airport outside Kuala Lumpur. GEC has also sold defence equipment to Malaysia under the controversial 1988 memorandum of understanding between the two countries. Malaysian officials privately admit that Dr Mahathir is unlikely to take any quick decision to rescind his government's order against British companies. It is felt that Dr Mahathir wants a more outspoken condemnation from Downing Street of reports in the British media - in particular a report in The Sunday Times - alleging that he and other members of the Malaysian government had been involved in seeking under-the-table payments from a British company.
DOC.CN: MYZ Malaysia, Asia. GBZ United Kingdom, EC.
DOC.IN: P9721 International Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FT 09 MAR 94 / Heseltine rejects role as next Tory chairman
DOC.TEXT: Mr Michael Heseltine has dismissed suggestions from prominent Tory MPs that he should take over as Conservative party chairman after the government's expected defeats in local and European elections this summer. His determination to stay at the Department of Trade and Industry emerged as Mr Kenneth Clarke, the chancellor, failed to dispel speculation that he and Mr Heseltine are preparing for a leadership contest later this year. Mr Clarke insisted during a series of interviews yesterday that he expected Mr John Major to lead the Conservatives into the general election due by 1997. That echoed Mr Major's public reaffirmation earlier this week of his determination to hold on to the premiership. But the chancellor, who said he was fed up with being quizzed about the leadership, again admitted his long-term ambitions to become prime minister. That and a couple of verbal slips suggesting that Mr Major's position was not entirely secure were seen at Westminster as evidence that Mr Clarke is anxious to keep open his options in the event of an early leadership crisis. Mr Heseltine has told close friends that he wants to remain in his present post when Mr Major unveils his expected cabinet reshuffle after the summer elections. He has not received any indication from 10 Downing Street that the prime minister will seek to move him. The speculation that Mr Major might ask Mr Heseltine to lead the Conservatives' campaign for the next general election has been fanned by intense suspicion on the right of the Tory party that he is positioning himself for a leadership bid. Prominent rightwing Tory MPs have been openly canvassing the idea that by making him party chairman Mr Major could ensure Mr Heseltine's loyalty if bad results in the local and European polls trigger a leadership crisis. Sir Norman Fowler, the present chairman, has already indicated his plan to stand down and the MPs have suggested that Mr Heseltine would find it impossible to turn down the job without appearing disloyal. But friends of Mr Heseltine have dismissed as nonsense any suggestion that he would pose a threat to the prime minister if he remained at the DTI. The trade and industry secretary has made it clear that he has always regarded his task of reshaping the government's approach to industry as one that would take at least three years and probably longer. Mr Heseltine's unwillingness to countenance a move leaves Mr David Hunt, employment secretary, as the clear favourite for the party chairmanship.
DOC.IN: P9199 General Government, NEC.
